description:
Pretty good spot to get Mexican food in Noe Valley! 

I was walking by and was looking for a spot to have a quick bite. I walked in and ordered a  burrito, nothing complicated, just a simple grilled chicken with black bean and rice burrito. You walk I. And place order at this place. Then you pick a table with your number and they bring out the food in a few minutes. 

The burrito even as simple as mine (you can opt for fancier burrito) taste so good. The salsa they had in it was spicy, yet flavourful and the grilled chicken ( pollo asada)was really good. The size was perfect for me, not too big or small and really hot the spot. I ordered an agua fresca (watermelon) which also taste very fresh and accompanied the burrito perfectly. 

Service was great and very helpful. Prices were very reasonable as well. Place was clean and peaceful to enjoy your food. Parking is also street meter parking with the 24 Divisadero line stopping at 24th/Castro streets a few doors down from the restaurant.
author: Albie E.

description:
i have always ordered the little chihuahua from either postmates or caviar and i have never had a bad meal, ever.  they are as consistent as the sun coming up each morning.  

all of their ingredients are fresh and flavorful.  we usually get the steak burrito and it is always lean meat so you never take a bite and get a piece of "grizzle".  they add avocado (you can get guacamole but i love the avocado) and it add such a bright, creamy flavor.  

this is definitely the best mexican take out in sf.
author: Samantha B.

description:
I ordered the regular enchilada. One with green sauce and one with sauce. The corn tortillas were mad chewy and old tasting. Not good. Nothing special really, the salsas were arite. but the chewy and hard tortillas were not good. why. also, overpriced. 

black refried beans were pretty good, i'll give a star for that.
author: Shruti D.

description: OK,  I had the special al pastor pork tacos last night (close to closing) and they were *killer*.  Bravo!
author: Don N.

description: The food is good, I can't complain, but it's not super friendly. The lady manager looks dumpy and was not particularly friendly. At least the background music, which was generic Rock instead of some nice Latin music, was turned down.
author: David A.

description:
This was slowly becoming l a fave, until I walked in a couple of weeks ago after they'd just opened for the day, and I see the cooks preparing/organizing food at their station...without gloves, which they're normally wearing. I get it, the law requiring them to wear gloves was repealed, but if they're normally wearing them, you know I'm gonna be shocked when they're not. 

I'm a nurse, this hep. A stuff is real. I'm not about it.....
author: Gabriela W.

description:
Solid takeout option, especially if you look for organic ingredients and grass fed meat. 

My gluten free "healthyish" order is the carne asada salad without the shell. Definitely want to get the habanero salsa, a perfect heat level. 

If you find yourself in Noe Valley and need something casual, most everyone could find something they like there. However don't go out of your way to come here. 

Skip the tortilla chips but make sure you get the habanero.
author: Anna S.

description: We are visiting SF for four days this is our second trip. It's chilly and im all about the soup! Had the posole the other day and the chicken tortilla soup tonight and I'm in love. I will miss this place when we leave. Great food, great prices and served hot, fresh, and plentifully.
author: Cheryl E.

description:
This review is for their catering service.
We hosted a small party for 18 ppl, and I didn't want to all the work. Since my husband loves tacos, I decided to reach out to a few local places that caters. Michael from TLC catering was super easy to work with, very helpful and responsive. 

On the day of the event, the food was delivered 5 minutes early, and Michael helped set everything up flawlessly. The food was abundant and yummy! I will absolutely work with them again for future events.
author: Mimi T.

description:
My typical rule of cheap Mexican food is that it's the salsas aren't good, then the food usually follows. To that end, the salsas are decent but have way too much acid (lime juice). The hot red salsa is probably the best of the bunch, and it goes great with the pastor on nachos or tacos.

I've been here a few times since this place is local. Overall the food is decent and maybe I'd give it 4 stars, but the prices are too expensive. A garlic and shrimp burrito for $16? I know you gotta charge a bit more to make it in SF but, seriously, I can't bring myself to pay that kinda scratch that when the mission is just around the corner. Also there's only beer and wine here, so if you want any hard liquor (i.e. a margarita) you gotta go somewhere else.

If there's anything redeeming about this place, it's the brunch. The chilaquiles are pretty decent (again, it's all about the salsa) and the breakfast burritos are serviceable. It's definitely a good option for a hangover since the other Mexican spot down the street doesn't open till 12pm.
author: Travis V.

description: I ordered a super carne asada burrito  with the glutton free tortilla here to-go. Paid a little over $14 for it. Which to me seems pretty expensive for a burrito. As I take it out the bag and take my first bite, I got nothing but a glob of refried beans and a bit of rice.  So I just said to myself,"they probably didn't mix it or portion it correctly." As I continue to eat it I started to get more rice but no protein. Five bites later, and I still couldn't find any protein. So I opened it up and found out THEY FORGOT TO PUT THE CARNE ASADA!!!!  this place is not worth it! Just go to to a legit taqueria and save your $$$ and you know that you'll get a legit burrito.
author: Dale D.

description:
For our office lunch last Friday, March 10th, I decided to order from The Little Chihuahua. My order arrived via Forkable a little before 12 noon.

Custom Tostada Salad ($11.95): Our signature salad made with your choice of a menu option, organic mixed greens, black beans, avocados, pico de gallo, queso fresco, cucumbers, mango salsa & roasted bell peppers with a lime-cilantro dressing served on top of a crispy tortilla shell
*Menu Option: Pollo Asado
*Add Extras: Carne Asada (+$3.75)
*Notes: No Beans, No Mango salsa, Extra Pico de gallo, Extra sides of Salsa

I've had this salad before and I really enjoyed it. For some reason, this time, it wasn't as good as I remember. The salad is still a huge portion. Really big and super hefty. Even without the tostada, it's a large size. I liked the meats, but the avocado wasn't creamy and the sides of salsa seemed chunky and dry. I wasn't a huge fan of the dressing, so I didn't really have anything to dress the salad with. It ended up being okay as it didn't really need a dressing due to the pico and the rest of the ingredients. One thing I just don't like about this dish is the cheese. Maybe if it was nice and melty it would have blended better, but it just didn't meld together with the cubes of queso fresco. I ended up picking them out of my salad.

Overall, an all right salad. And who doesn't like a salad with both steak and chicken? (Yes, my inner fattie does!) Still a very filling dish. It just wasn't as good as I remember.
author: Elena N.

description:
Fresh Mexican cooking with quality ingredients in a pristine, modern setting--that's what you'll find at the Little Chihuahua in Noe Valley! The place was fairly empty when I arrived for a weeknight dinner, so we ordered at the counter and the food was brought out quickly to us.

I got to try the grilled shrimp burrito, which came with rice, black beans, and avocado, and the tostada salad with pollo asado. Both of these were great dishes with clean flavors--I really enjoyed the salad, which came with cucumbers, peppers, greens, cheese, avocado, and even mangoes! It had a great crunch and fresh, vibrant flavors--my only complaint is that the tostada the salad came on was extremely greasy, so I didn't end up eating it. 

The salsa bar here is also amazing--there were at least four different types of salsas, including tomatillo and chipotle, and plenty of fresh pico de gallo! Though perhaps not the cheapest Mexican food around, you're definitely paying for the fantastic quality of ingredients!
author: David K.

description: This isn't like your typical taqueria in the Mission, so I don't think it's fair to compare it to anything. It's definitely a little fancier and pricier than the typical Mission taqueria, so it's different. I like going here because there are unique options. I love getting a Super Baby Burrito with chili verde chicken. It's a good size, not an insane amount of food, and the chicken is really well made! The salsa bar is also awesome. There are so many different kinds, and you can always get as much as you want. The tostada salad is also great - delicious greens, mango, veggies, and tostada bowl. I love coming here because it's high quality food for not too much while also being a quick and casual meal.
author: Steph V.

description:
Doesn't this look like a beauty: http://bit.ly/2iBqIB2? 

Little Chihuahua's Signature Tostada Salad w/ carne asada, mixed greens, black beans, avocado, queso fresco, cucumber, mango salsa, roasted bell peppers, lime-cilantro dressing ($12.45) is massive and full of vibrant colors so it must taste good, right?

Aye, chihuahua....it was no bueno. 

The carne asada was devoid of any seasoning and had the texture of a thick, rubber band - it was full of sinew making it impossible to swallow. The rest of the salad just had too much going on...cubed mango, huge chunks of cheese, huge chunks of cucumbers, and just way too much mushy bell peppers. Everything tasted muddled so I just ate around all the copious amount of stuff and stuck with the nicely dressed mixed greens...as a cow would. Except, I wasn't a happy cow with this salad.

I appreciate Little Chihuahua's concept of offering organic and sustainable Mexican food but as others have mentioned, this is Mexican food for yuppies. Nothing wrong with that (and all their locations cater to their demographics) but I rather drive a little further to The Mission or the Excelsior for legit Mexican food (hello, lengua and menudo!). 

Two stars for the salad but an extra star for the fast service (received my order in 5 minutes). 

But, what's up with all the fruit fries flying around and crawling on the table? Oh yah, organic.
author: Cherylynn N.

description: We love TLC, but the food is getting too spicy, especially the kids items. My daughter is very sensitive to hot spice and sometimes won't finish her taco. Anyway, you don't need to make the food so spicy. We don't buy the guacamole anymore because it's way too spicy. So please, stop adding the hot spice to your meats and guacamole. You have an excellent array of salsas to use which have a far better hot flavor. We will continue to eat at the TLC hoping that the spice will disappear.
author: Guy S.

description: What I ordered was delicious. The vegetarian taco...yum! Will definitely eat here again.
author: Melissa H.

description:
It's probably strange that I stopped here and got some organic / healthy "mexican" food when I was just a short walk away from some of the best taquerias buuuut I was starving so please forgive me. You order at the counter, take a number and they bring you your food. There's a pretty nice salsa bar and the staff is helpful. 

I got the tortilla soup and a side salad, the soup took 20+ mins because they were dealing with a ton of delivery orders :( It was good but kind of felt like it was missing a factor known as love (if that makes any sense -- it didn't go above and beyond in any way). For the price I paid, $14 total, I should've gone somewhere more authentic.
author: Hana S.

description:
Seeing the plantain burritos from Little Chihuahua on the menu warranted a trip over to check it out.......this had potential to be a brilliant menu offering & we were looking forward 

Result?  Too many peppers, not enough plantains or black beans

The flavor was okay but not spicy at all & I'd really been hoping for fewer peppers

Next time I'll ask them to hold the peppers & see how that works out - willing to try again for sure
author: Adrienne G.

description: Excellent gluten free options and tortilla!! I haven't had a quesadilla in years, it was damn good!! Quick, great fresh food! Love it, I'll be back!
author: Judy C.

description:
It's aight.  It's also expensive.  

The best thing about this place is the salsa bar.  The salsas are outstanding.  The burritos themselves are small.  And compared to the other offerings in the city... TLC needs to step it up (and cut its prices... come on.. it's Mexican food yo.)
author: Andrew P.

description:
Chihuahua sized portions!
Walked in and was greeted by a man behind the register (let's call him hipster bro) who when asked how the chorizo was said "I dunno man, I don't eat pork but people seem to like it"....OK thanks. So I proceed to order a burrito with beans, cheese, and rice, with carne asada and chorizo, without anything else...$12.XX!! OK, they use high quality ingredients, prolly worth it....
Hipster bro goes away and comes back and attends to other customers...who were not next in line.
After 10 minutes, my burrito is ready, except it's the size of a Taco Bell burrito or a large churro!!! There was more tortilla than anything else inside! Chipotle's burrito is 2x the size, Whole Food's is 3x the size and $4 cheaper! 
I expressed my surprise at the size of the burrito and hipster bro goes "sorry".
Walk out and start eating it, then get frustrated by layers of tortilla and turn back to come inside. Tell the other cashier that when someone orders a burrito and there aren't some ingredients (like salsa or guac) to fill up the rest of burrito with rice or beans at least!
WHAT A RIP OFF! Sorry no burrito, even in SF, unless it's the size of my head, is worth $12!
Not going back there again!
author: Alec N.

description: A quality taqueria! I have been to the mothership on di-vis and this outpost did not disappoint... great fresh tacos with a beer on the side, friendly staff, good prices, little patio or if you prefer a large front window! Nice!
author: Reg B.

description:
Darn it Little Chihuahua, it seems like you guys can't get your act together and make the food that people order. 

I've gotten take out five times in the last two months and every time something is wrong with my order. Added rice when I asked for no rice. Wrong kind of beans. And the one that you guys are zero for five on is every time I've ordered a super burrito, you miss the sour cream, the guacamole, the cheese, or all three. What gives??!
author: Susan J.

description:
This place does not stack up against other Mexican joints in this city. (Disclaimer: this review is based on one dish only). In my opinion, you can very accurately rate the quality of any Mexican restaurant by the quality of its chilaquiles. Sadly, the Little Chihuahua came up quite short with this dish. 

Their biggest mistake, and it's quite unforgivable, is serving scrambled eggs atop what can most kindly be describes as mushy Doritos. SCRAMBLED EGGS! Can you imagine the horror on my face when I saw a fluffy yellow pillow of egg nesting itself upon the soggy sadness that lied beneath? I was devastated. The highlight of every chilaquiles dish is the excitement that accompanies sticking your fork into a shiny, bulging, golden yolk and watching the fatty flavor balloon burst, dripping ever so delicately down the rest of the dish. The Yappy Chihuahua deprived me of this experience. 

Otherwise, the flavors are just okay.
author: Jim B.

description: I love this place. Definitely my favorite all-around Mexican place to eat here in the city. Been to all three locations (Divisadero, Valencia and 24th St) and never had a bad experience with the food or service. I love the traditional Mission-style burritos (Cancun, Pancho Villa, Farolito) and the more unusual offerings at La Palma, but this place is different: healthier ingredients and preparation. The garlic shrimp burrito and the guacamole enchiladas are fantastic, good fish tacos, yummy quesadillas, and great fresh salsa selection (they charge extra for chips but they're thick and crunchy and served warm and you'll want them to sample all those delicious salsas). I'm pesco-vegetarian so I can't comment on the meat entrees. Large portions. Certainly more expensive than the popular taquerias but also healthier and definitely worth it.
author: Ferrara P.

description: Popped in this place for an early lunch while in the Noe Valley neighborhood. I had the grilled fish taco and the black bean plantain taco - both served on corn tortillas. Delicious! A little overpriced at $5-7 per taco at a counter service place would be my only complaint.
author: Jena G.

description:
My wife loves the chicken chile verde tacos here. They looked good  today and  they met her mark. 
My burrito, on the other hand, was rice  and beans with a minute smattering of tasteless carnitas.  Given the many great burritos in SF, why not in Noe valley. 
Aside from the disappointing food, the place was bleak if you go away from the 24th street windows.
I want to support local businesses, but they need to provide a great product.
author: Richard D.

description: Hate this place, horrible customer service and never get the order correct. Expensive and food is not worth it. Will never recommend are eat at this shit hole again.
author: Jermaine T.

description: One of my favorite Mexican food places. The best grilled chicken in the city. Never disappoints.
author: Veronica G.

description:
Same good food with an updated interior.

I still recommend:
stacked enchilada (weekend brunch only)
tostada salad
plantain burrito w/black beans

They added fish tacos to the menu. I tried them...meh.

It's bougie Noe Valley Mexican with a Noe Valley price tag, but it's still good. Oh, yeah, you have to pay for chips now.
:(
author: El B.

description: They were super busy, seemed to be very popular but honestly don't get what all the fuss is about. The salsa bar was great and the meat seems to be of good quality. What really turned me off from this place is the fact that the food was extremely spiced and honestly didn't taste much like Mexican food, in my opinion it tasted similar to middle eastern food which I do enjoy, but not if I'm trying to enjoy a traditional Mexican dish. On top of it it's a pretty pricey place. The staff was very kind even though they were extremely busy.
author: Shannon H.

description: Ordered a $14 chicken  burrito here.  Just about inedible.  Over-priced, terrible food.  Won't ever go back.
author: Malcolm L.

description: I was craving Mexican food for lunch and this was the only place near my job, so I decided to give it a shot. The first thing I noticed was the price. I was only getting two tacos and I was paying over $10. I ordered the carne asada taco and the shrimp taco. I was impressed with their tortillas, but other than that the food is beyond BLAND. The menu states that you get guacamole in your tacos and I got none. Rip off. The shrimp in the shrimp taco are not juicy. It looks like the shrimp had been sitting in lime juice. I did that once at home and totally ruined my shrimp. I wouldn't go back. It's not worth the price and it's noting compared to other Mexican food restaurants. Nice try Little Chihuahua.
author: Brenda S.

description:
This place is freaking fantastic. Used to eat here at least twice a week. After you've tried this, other Mexian food joints really pales in comparison. It's all about the assessors - sauces, sides and details! Love!!
 I can't eat here anymore since I live on the east coast now - Open The Little Chihuahua in D.C. please!!
author: Hasti R.

description: Tried this after searching for breakfast burritos and this place was great. Also had the mex French toast which was a tasty, interesting twist on the traditional. Cute back area, and the salsa bar was excellent.
author: Matt W.

description:
Came here with good company a few weeks ago for a Saturday night meal. Little Chihuahua has been on my list for some time because hello, plantain burrito sounds ah-may-zing. It's located in a cute little part of Noe Valley, where parking is a bit annoying to find.

OVERALL.
+ Decent amount of seating (although not great for large groups)
+ Friendly, relatively fast service
+ Good selection of drinks (beer, margaritas, etc)
~ Pretty decent food (although not really authentic, more fusion-y)
~ Expected price-points for the food quality and neighborhood

I wouldn't return, simply because there are so many other options out there, but it's not bad for a quick bite.
author: Claire S.

description:
The little chihuahua is a little more demure compared to the hustle and bustle of most tacquerias towards the Mission, but the food is pretty good, albeit not being "authentic".

Our favorite items were the salmon tacos and plantain/black bean burrito. Though the salmon was a bit on the dry side, the cilantro cream salsa was definitely its saving grace. Paired with the crunch from the picked onion and the cabbage slaw, this was definitely a bite worth taking. As for the plantain/black bean burrito, the sweet and savory mix was definitely interesting. Yeah, maybe the burrito was a little more mushy than I would have liked, but it still piqued my tastebuds.

Other things we tried:
Garlic Shrimp Burrito - definitely a hit on the garlic, but bay shrimp? Really? And several of them still had a shell on. 
Al Pastor Taco - the pineapple salsa was a real let down in my opinion. Perhaps it was just a bit skimpy, cause it just wasn't there.

A tiny salsa bar is available. My favorite dips were the roasted tomato salsa and fresh pico!
author: Elaine Y.

description: Really average burritos. In the al pastor burrito, for example, nothing about the meat, rice, beans, or wrap really stood out, making for an overall humdrum meal. It's a larger venue than meets the eye, and is family-friendly given the neighborhood, but is otherwise just... bland.
author: Vincent L.

description:
Kind of Americanized, okay fine, completely Americanized Mexican food. 

I've been to other TLC before, and this one is located in Noe Valley. Cute neighborhood with lots of shopping and food options.

The food here was pretty darn good. The shrimp salad and baby burrito hit my post work hunger spot. 

The salsa bar has many options as well. 

Parking sucks but hey, its the city, what do you expect?
author: Nika K.

description:
Ate the Garlic Shrimp Burrito...

There was no bite in my entire burrito that brought any kind of joy, and I love eating!  It looks like a burrito yet it's just a texture.  If I were to rate it in terms of eyebrow raising good, I'd give it a quarter of one eyebrow; it was more a quizzical look though. 

The eating experience can be compared to showing up to a concert all pumped up and ready to party, and the sound engineer accidentally pulls the plug on the house PA.  You hear little parts that remind you of the song, but you really can't hear everything.

I tasted the shrimp; just your basic cooked shrimp; a bit overcooked like it was stewing all day.  I tasted bits of garlic, which was really the only flavor really sitting in front.  The rice was just orange, pasty mush.  Usually it should have some aroma or fragrance if you want your burrito to have some character.  The black beans tasted like black beans should, so nothing bad there, just what you'd expect.  

In a last ditch effort the burrito could have been saved if the salsas were any good.  The only thing urging me to cross the finish line was adding pico de gallo to each bite.  

I don't think the ingredients were old, I just think nobody cares if it tastes good. 

If you're hungry, need a burrito that bad, and are too lazy to go to a better place, then have at it, but don't expect to enjoy any part of the whole getting-it-into-your-belly thing.  

The name of this place is great though.  I think that's the only reason why they're actually getting any business.  Chihuahuas are cute.  Why would anything with a chihuahua associated with it suck?

J
author: John M.

description: Had the grilled shrimp burrito with a sangria -- ate the whole thing! Nice spot for lunch, good tunes, and child friendly.
author: Ivonne M.

description:
gringo mex for yuppies and their brood.

Good for noe valley families and kids but i would rather go to the mission and get a real burrito
author: Zk K.

description: I always get the plantain and black bean burrito. Good vegan options!
author: Ben L.

description:
Little Chihuahua is a neighborhood classic, providing healthy Mexican food, with an eye toward great ingredients and a good family feel. 

Like most Noe Valley restaurants, they are very child friendly, and this location does a particularly good job of making you feel fine having toddlers running all around the place (they're always in good company). 

My go to order is the enchiladas with red sauce, usually split between one mushroom and one guacamole, both come with cheese. They come with corn tortillas not flour, which is good.
author: Mike G.

description: Overpriced and they charge extra for chips.  Luke warm takeout Burritos most of the time.  I hardly ever go there. I usually get mad at myself for giving them another chance when I do.
author: Monte C.

description: Good food, friendly staff. Can vouch for the carnitas, tostada salad and salsa bar. Breakfast burrito on the other hand is bland, under spiced, potatoes aren't crispy... It's also a tad expensive.
author: Nate G.

description: Love little chihuahua nachos and burritos, but this is super expensive- probably because it's in Noe Valley.  The front staff is always so polite and kind, but there have been multiple occasions where women I know have felt very uncomfortable with the staring by 2 of the chefs.Hopefully management can put an end to that because it's not okay to make people feel like that.
author: S B.

description: Got a beans and rice burrito and it was the blandest thing I have ever gotten in the mission area. Take a trek to Papalote if you want a quick place to dine in or any authentic taqueria in the mission. The prices are way to high for what you get and full of kids.
author: Brittany A.

description:
Please re-open sometime soon? 

TLC is my only go to place for dinner in Noe Valley and has easily become a once a week visit for me.  I enjoy how quick the staff is and how consistently delicious the food is.  I look forward to the TLC re-opening or remodeling? not quite sure but please re-open SOON.

THANKS!
author: Andrew T.

description:
Very Americanized establishment. Not the experience I was hoping. 

The drink (orchata) was too sweet, the service was subpar, and the food had no authenticity. 

A small step up from Taco Bell.
author: Victor T.

description:
First time and most likely my last.
Today, on April 4th, aka "equal pay day", I friend suggested I should try it AND was told they were participating in the 20% discount.
So, I arrive about 5:00 PM; there is a display right on the counter advertising the equal pay day discount, and at the end they didn't honor it. I inquired as to why and the young lady said: oh, that was earlier in the day.
Now, the burrito was decent, not great for the price AND NO CHIPS...unless you pay extra!
I believe I will stick to the dinners East of Dolores from now on when I'm in the mood for Mexican.
author: Colleen F.

description: Love this place and their delicious plantain burrito. i'm a flexi-tarian, so I eat meat too. and their carnitas and pollo are also winners. they recently underwent a cool renovation which looks great at night as well as the daytime.  the tables and entire restaurant are always so clean, even with all the kids that tromp through. the staff is awesome when you place your order, as well as when they are walking the floor and checking on guests. They offer filtered water and the BEST salsa bar in town. Tomatillo and the pico-de-gallo are my 2 favorites, and the bins are always refilled and so so fresh. I would cross town to visit this Mexican restaurant, but thankfully I'm only a 10 minute walk from the Castro!
author: Ron W.

description:
Ay! Chihuahua! 

I love this place. It's very SF, meaning organic, grass fed beef, whole wheat tortillas kind of place.
This is great for me, a vegetarian that loves burritos. I'm always looking for a good veggie burrito. Unfortunately the more authentic places are not so great for vegetarians. Also, I'm very picky...I was able to order a grilled veggie, no onion, black bean, whole wheat, avocado - not guacamole, but with sour cream burrito  AND they didn't even skip a beat.   I love a good salsa bar and Chihuahua's delivers. Some of the salsas are hot, no joke. They serve drinks too!  Not the cheapest but a good casual place.  I've been to the Divisadero & Noe locations and both are great.
author: Jessica D.

description: Fresh, (relatively) healthy Mexican. Servings are a good size... I typically order the tostada salad and always have leftovers. The salsa bar is consistently flavorful, although given the price of the entrees I was a bit annoyed when they started charging for tortilla chips. TLC is definitely more expensive than most fast casual restaurants but the quality and freshness is what keeps me coming back.
author: Lara T.

description:
Clean and reliable, I can see how the Noe Crowd might like this.  Lots of kids and their moms. And workers on their tablets having lunch.

Food wasn't quite flavored to my personal taste.  
Shrimp garlic burrito not only had more than a few fishy tasting (old) shrimp, but just didn't come together taste wise.   
Pozole had a beautiful deep red color, but didn't taste like it looked.  It needed to be more flavorful or sour--even limes did not help.
Chips were also so-so--not salty enough.

However, I can say the salsa bar was better than most places, even without limes (now very expensive, onions, and cilantro).  And Strawberry Agua Fresca wasn't bad.  

Mostly because the shrimp in my burrito was not reliably fresh, I don't feel like returning.  I'll stick with La Espiga D'oro as my personal favorite in terms of best tasting and best value.
author: Philip L.

description: Not impressed. Typical hipster restaurant with very Americanized "Mexican" food. It's slightly above Taco Bell and bordering Chipotle. Maybe someone who has never had a decent Mexican dish would like it, but if you want real Mexican go elsewhere.
author: Laura S.

description: I think this is the Chipotle of Noe Valley, which basically means it's pretty pricey. I got a chicken chile verde quesadilla. It was really tasty, but also $11.50!!! And we had to pay an extra $1 for a bowl of chips. The chips were crisp and fresh, but NOT free, just like Chipotle. But I would definitely say that they tasted better than Chipotle chips. And they also have a fresh salsa bar where you help yourself to whichever salsa you want. My quesadilla was a good size and really good, but the side of guac was small and thin, just a thin coating on top of a pile of raw shredded cabbage. The portion size was decent, so I had some leftovers that heated up fairly nicely later that afternoon. I would consider returning if I want fast Mexican food in Noe, but I would probably want to try some other brunch places first.
author: Leslie H.

description:
Nice little place for a quick meal or takeout. 

-FAST, friendly service. (Shoutout to the awesome dude behind the counter who gave me a taste of the jicama agua fresca)
-Salsa bar (not terribly exciting to be honest, but kind of nice) 
-Reasonably priced

I ordered the Carne asada taco salad and enjoyed it.  Really large portion and the actual steak was yummy. I believe the menu said it was served with queso fresco, however the cheese was identical to feta which was kind of weird in a taco salad. Shredded cheese is so wonderful in these kinds of salads so that would've taken the dish to another level. However, I was still very content because of the mango salsa, flavorful black beans and avocado. 

My friend got the salmon tacos and they were really generous with the fish and apparently very tasty, too!
author: Sara M.

description:
Pricy, but delicious. Warm, fresh, homemade tortilla chips- my second favorite part of the meal next to the margarita. It was an agave wine margarita with freshly squeezed orange juice and sliced prances I. The drink. Not a fan of tequila so this was a pleasant surprise! We ordered the super burrito to split and it was the perfect amount. The steak was so fresh and delicious!
Atmosphere was clean and fun!
Go Here!
author: Ali H.

description:
So I'm one of those people who thinks Chipotle makes the best burrito ever. I get burritos other places, but to me, Chipotle was always my favorite. Enter The Little Chihuahua. My husband and I tried this place during our first couple days living in Noe Valley and it is actually better than Chipotle. For me to say that is a big deal. I am actually surprised it only has 3.5 stars. You know how there are those restaurants with 3.5 stars that you love, and the ones that are really terrible - well, this one is one of the good ones. We shared the Pollo Asado super burrito with black beans. It's a little more expensive than Chipotle, but it's definitely worth it!

This place definitely has to-go food, but it won't be quite as quick as Chipotle. I'd expect a to wait a few minutes in line and another 4 or 5 minutes to get your food. Some crazy lady literally started screaming in the restaurant about waiting for your food. Relax, woman! Luckily, a man behind us lightened the mood by immediately screaming about wanting to order (making fun of the crazy lady), so it was an entertaining visit to say the least.

It's not a place where you see all the ingredients in front of you already prepared and choose from behind a glass window. The cooks assemble make your food in the kitchen, though you can see them well.
author: Kendra N.

description: I got the super burrito with pollo asado and red guajillo sauce...it was fresh with lots of meat. Very fresh and delicious. Would go there again and try other entrees.
author: Steven J.

description:
Seems expensive, but the ingredients were fresh tasting and concientiously sourced.  It was $35 for 2 burritos, two drinks, and chips and guac.  Is that normal now? 

I had the green chili tofu, and it was great.  The plantain burrito was also delicious if you like roasted bananas.  The chips were disappointing, and the salsas that I tried were bland.  So overall, it was okay, but I probably will go other places before trying this one again.
author: Norman H.

description:
Ehhhhhh. Food was sub par at best. Ordered the carnitas super burrito with red sauce, boyfriend ordered the al pastor with red sauce.. When we got our food, it's wasn't even hot. It was warmish. I asked the guy if he could warm it up, and they brought me a completely new burrito, which I thanked them for.. When I bit into it, the tortilla was hot, but yet again the meat/rice combo was warmish. 

Other than that, the food didn't taste very great. Meat didn't have much flavor and tortilla was too thick. The salsas were pretty good, though. The staff were all nice, and helpful. But I wouldn't go out of my way to come here again.
author: Lisette C.

description:
I've long enjoyed the food here. You can't go wrong with any of the burritos, salad, or (my favorite) pozole. Fresh, quality taqueria fare, and twists like the cilantro slaw take it up a notch. 

But I'm disappointed by the remodel, which is cold and offputting. The larger waiting area (clearly for takeout pickups) is dimly lit, and the menu board is gone, so it's very hard to read the tiny-print menu whether you take out or eat in. The eating area also has that cold feel, and is far less enjoyable than the older design. It's now a place where it's best to order ahead and just pick up, not walk into to order and certainly not to stay. Sad.
author: Galen G.

description:
Price is good, ingredients are good and service is great.

This place should be a solid yelp 4 stars. It's a great option when cooking isnt one.

Whelmed. Fully whelmed. Not under or over. Just whelmed. Thanks TLC.
author: Eamonn M.

description: came here to pick up dinner tonight and everything was tasty - huge portions and they are very generous with the meat too - got a carne asada super burrito and a carne asada nacho - both with that red sauce (just a tad of heat with some sweetness) - will be our go-to Mexican place from now on
author: Mia C.

description:
Cute Noe Valley location.  We came on a Sunday night in October and found close street parking.  It was a bit crowded, even for a Sunday night, and we managed to get a table to sit.

We had the enchilada, both the wild mushroom one and the vegetarian one.  Also, had two tacos, al pastor and carne asada.  For drinks, a watermelon and a pineapple agua fresca.  Everything was good, and there was a good selection of salsas, too.  The counter service was very friendly and helpful.

I would definitely come back if in the area again.
author: Dan L.

description:
I'd give this place 2.5 stars. I really had high hopes for this place after reading all the glowing reviews from yelp for both locations. However, the food left alot to be desired.

I ordered the specialty Al Pastor Burrito:  al pastor pork grilled with sautéed onions,
poblanos & grilled pineapple salsa on a toasted tortilla with jack cheese, smoky chile salsa, pico de gallo, fresh cilantro & onions, whole black beans and rice. I typically don't order al pastor or anything with pineapple. I don't know why I deviated because this entire combination  and the flavors just were not good at all. I took a few bites and left the rest uneaten. I thought I'd save it for later, but later came and there was absolutely no interest in it. 

The bf ordered a quesadilla and he was also not impressed, although he did manage to finish the whole thing so it could not have been that bad.

We also ordered the carne asada nachos which was decent enough. I filled my stomach on this while my burrito got left uneaten.

I did love the salsa bar... that sadly was the only plus to this restaurant though. To satisfy my mex food cravings I'll continue to hit up El Faralito.
author: Pauline T.

description:
I'm hovering between a 2 and 3 stars. 

Opted for the "super baby" since I wanted a small-ish burrito but not a "dumbed down" version (just bean and cheese) as I was looking for all the proper fillings of a standard sized burrito. What I got was a burrito, wrapped with DRY tortilla that I would easily have passed over for a Taco Bell's 7-Layer (similar in size) that I could have got for less than 1/4 the price here. Not to mention the bag of tortilla chips that I received were going stale. 

I can't say it was a BAD burrito but was disappointing for the price.
author: Esther A.

description:
Delicious salsa, bean options, and the food is so full of flavor!

My new favorite place to get Mexican in Noe!
author: T. C.

description:
Terrible beer selection! No ales at all - nothing but lagers. 
The food is good and my wife says the Sangria is excellent. But no ales? Come on guys, you can do better than this.
author: Nicholas D.

description: I've been frequenting this place for years - beginning with the Divisidero location - and I'm big on the specialty burritos, love the selection of sauces (we can freely take as much as we want home), and the chill vibe - ESPECIALLY at the Noe Valley location. Yes, there will often be families in attendance, which means strollers, but the staff are often kind and approachable. VEGETARIAN/VEGANS - try the Black Bean Burrito with sweet plantains!!!
author: Kristina B.

description:
I want to love this place.  The food is consistently good, they use organic, sustainable ingredients, and I don't feel like I am risking hepatitis by just walking in like I do at so many SF burrito joints.

But the service is just lame.  Been three times in two weeks.  First time, skinny bearded hipster dude didn't know how to work the register and put my order in.  So of course he impatiently asked me to slow down, like my life's mission was to put him out.  Second time, they forgot to put in our entire order and when we called to get a refund they said they didn't know how.  Tonight, when I was on my way to the restaurant, my wife called ahead to find out what the grilled vegetables were. The same skinny hipster dude said 1) he didn't know and 2) it was too busy for him to find out, and he hung up on her. Five minutes later I walked in....while it wasn't crickets it certainly wasn't busy.  And the kitchen is literally two steps from the register.

The kitchen staff seemed great but the front of house needs to lose the 'tude. They can go back and write poetry or put ironic  stickers on their laptops on their time; just take my order and get it right on my time.
author: Rob H.

description: My kids and I love the little chihuahua burritos, but since the restaurant remodel, the size of the burrito is not as substantial as it once was. I ordered a regular size burrito with beans, rice and cheese for my 6 year old and a kid's bean and cheese burrito for my 3 year old. They were practically the same size! I love their flavors, but for the price and the amount of food you get, I don't think we can continue eating here. It's not a family friendly price point considering I have to buy two $9 burritos to fill my young daughter's belly. We will miss you little chihuahua.
author: Annie H.

description:
Woke up a bit late during the day and a bit of hungover from last night. It was too late for breakfast when all of a sudden I was craving for Mexican food. So, we decided to come here again to check out what they have on their menu. I am a meat lover at heart and decided to try their carne asada nachos again. Why again do you asks? It's because I love nachos with lots of guacamole and sour cream on top. Plus, I always like their free chips and salsa. Did I mention their salsa, my favorite is their roasted tomatoes.

Anyhoo, they either changed they cook or gotten really good at making the nachos because that time it was the best nachos I've ever tasted. And to top it all off, I had to order my favorite agave wine margarita. I like a strong drink to kick me right off the bat other than drinking something that tasted like water. Love their margarita, first sip and it's like "boom their goes the dynamite" kick ass drink kind of margarita!!!

So, I come here because their delicious food & drinks. They have a lovely back patio to chill out and eat on a warm weather. The place is always clean whenever you come in. Love their wooden tables and chairs. They don't wobble either like some other restaurants. That's one of my pet peeves in case you haven't noticed! ;) Pretty good price considering they're located in Noe Valley but I'm glad my hun found this little gem! 

So, hope you guys try this joint out and let me know what you think.
author: Jackie A.

description: I'm not sure why these guys only have 3.5 stars. I live right around the corner and this is my go to place for some quality Mexican food. It's a order at the counter and sit down place, but the food is amazing! Also great to swing by and grab a burrito to go. My wife loves their salmon burrito! There are places in the mission that have a better burrito, but this is my favorite in Noe Valley!
author: Maek K.

description:
Review by A.K., 1st Grader:

When you walk past The Little Chihuahua your stomach starts to rumble! you can't help going in. The service is great. Their chips are the best chips in the world! You should take a bite of their cheesy pinto bean burritos. They are my favorite, but the salads are good too. Go to the Little Chihuahua on 24th Street. On a scale of 1-100, I would say 100!!!!
author: Eric G.

description: I used to love this place for their veggie plantain burritos. Until yesterday when I got a piece of chicken stuck to it. No refunds, guys. Nothing extra or free was offered, just a quick apology. Obviously the level of cross-contamination in their kitchen is pretty high. If you are omnivorous, that wouldn't be a problem. But as a plant-based eater I am not supporting this place anymore. Second star for salsa bar and being organic.
author: Elisabeth C.

description:
Just wanted to put in a hearty recommendation for the Noe Valley location of Little Chihuahua as an event space.  We contacted them last month about putting together a brunch for the morning of after our wedding.  They happily obliged, reserving the restaurant for our party the first hour of opening and printing up a special menu.  The whole event went off without a hitch, all of our guests loved it, and the final result was very reasonable in price compared to a buy-out option at other restaurants.  We had about 40 guests, and it seems like they could have handled 10-20 more.  

Don't know the next time we'll be back with a party this size, but we'll definitely be back for food!  Love their chilaquiles.
author: Sam M.

description:
I'll just say this: I used to leave my house, call them to place a to-go order, and arrive there in 12ish min with amazement that my food was already sitting on the counter ready to go. I realized this was a result of their superb and insanely fast service! Now I don't even call in because the guy behind the cash register is friendly and efficient and the cooks are super speedy. 

I've never waited more than 10min. for my take out order, which is generally the plantain burrito on a whole wheat tortilla (yum). Complimentary chips and salsa. They're never weird about substitutions and the food always hits the spot.

What else do you want in your local Mexican joint?
author: Ruth R.

description:
Probably the best burrito in Noe. The plantain burrito is fantastic and the fajita one too. You'll get one of the best burritos in town with no waiting time!
The other little chihuahuas always have a 45min line but this one doesn't!
author: Joffrey T.

description:
This place is my go-to burrito joint! The garlic shrimp burrito is the best I've ever had!

Sometimes there's a very long line, so calling ahead to order can make the experience easier.
author: E. S.

description: loved my tostada salad with avocado and carnitas!! such a healthy and delicious meal for only $13!! nice vibe, friendly staff - it was my first time here and I'm already looking forward to coming back!
author: Irena S.

description:
I thought this place was pretty good !! I got the shrimp garlic burrito , large chips & a soda .

It had a pretty big seating area inside & a nice patio outside . 

The person that was taking my order was nice and gave good customer service .

It's a little overpriced , but then again you do get what you pay for & I think what I got was very tasty & fresh . I like how my burrito wasn't greasy and fattening !! I definitely was in a food coma after this place :) 

You do have to clear your plates from the table after .. but if I am paying that much I feel like they should have someone busing the tables for us

But overall I would highly recommend you try it out !!!
author: Brittani P.

description:
My friends and I came here because we randomly searched a good Mexican place on yelp. The name intrigued us .. The little Chihuahua ? What an eye catcher! Also, the "Top Tip" was "garlic shrimp burrito" and my friend Melissa's eyes instantly lit up. This was the place to go. 

We ordered the garlic shrimp burrito, Carne Asada taco, salmon taco, and pollo asado nachos. 

-Nachos: average ... it looked better than it tasted. The grilled chicken was bland.
-Garlic Shrimp Burrito:  Shrimp was very garlicky and shrimpy hence "garlic shrimp burrito. They did not skimp on the shrimp! Definitely recommend this!
Carne Asada Taco: Reallly good! 
Salsa Bar: Big selection! Yummmm

Overall: Pricey for mexican food. WAY more authentic places in San Francisco! Probably wouldn't come back =(
author: Daniel S.

description:
Good place for lunch since I work near by
I had the Camarones tostada salad and it was good. Fresh ingredients friendly staff 
Will be back to try their tortilla soup.
author: C. M.

description:
I'm a sucker for Mexican food, so when my husband found this place, I was all about trying it out.  A good spot for grabbing a quick bite for lunch/dinner.  The burritos were pretty good - and the salsa bar was a nice addition.  They are generous on the amount of guac they give you as well; however, the guac we had was okay at best...there was even some left over, which NEVER happens when I'm around ;)

I think overall this place is a 3 1/2 stars.
author: Rachael S.

description: I saw this restaurant on Check Please so tonight my family and I went to try it out. Main reason for trying it out was because they said it was kid friendly. Of course the salsa bar helped also. Yes, it is truly kid friendly. Not one person in the place was childless at that time. We had a pretty good understanding that it wasn't authentic Mexican food from watching Check Please.It's definitely not authentic Mexican but it's fresh and tasty non the less. The reason I'm giving it 4 instead of 5 is because I can't get over the fact that everything you order is not what you would expect. I guess I should be more open minded cause it was great service, good fresh food and the ambience was totally relaxed kid friendly.
author: No P.

description:
If you can tolerate listening to the obnoxious noe valley house wives moan and complain about how life is so hard between yoga class and walking their pure bred dog, then it is worth the trip. 

Best burrito's in the city!  Excellent salsa!  And the staff was very friendly!  Larger than the divisadaro location so was easier to get a seat.
author: Daniel A.

description: Screw this place. They charge me $11 for a vegetarian burrito, screw it up, AND want an extra $0.50 for tortilla chips?! Ridiculous. Even though I live around the corner, I won't be visiting this white-washed attempt at Mexican food again.
author: Jennifer L.

description: That's it,  I'm through with you Little Chihuahua.    You can't seem to get an order right for us.    And our "super" burritos to-go tonight truly lived up to your name.  They were the littlest, teensiest, burritos I've ever had in San Francisco.    They were the size of other places' baby burritos.  And at $10.95 a pop, that is unacceptable.    Plus,  we ordered grilled vegetables and neither burrito had any.   And I ordered pintos but got refried instead.  And no rice.   Was there guacamole in there?   Couldn't tell.
author: Kathy B.

description:
I've been coming here since it first opened a couple years back.

Very consistent Mexican food and a clean, welcoming interior. I tend to get the same thing (baby burrito with carne asada and refried beans) but I've tried their tortilla soup, quesadillas and a couple of other items.

The quesadillas are massive and I have to say their carne asada is always moist and tender.

The staff is cool (especially that cutie Tess) and I usually place an order to pick up. 

Oh yeah, their horchatas are some of the best in the city! Nothing to blow your mind away but as I said, I very consistent option in Noe Valley.
author: Art O.

description: This place was a total disappointment. Not only was the food bad, but the service was even worse. My family and I -- 4 people total -- ordered burritos, a quesadilla and taco salads. All were bland and were a sad mix of traditional Mexican and nouveau California cuisine. We paid a dollar for a bowl of Chips--most of which were cracked pieces too tiny to even pick up. The place was dark and the employee at the counter didn't have the courtesy to tell there was a salsa bar in an adjacent area. Then as we were eating the employees flashed the indoor lights to let us know the place was closing, a rude act that was nothing compared to the mad dog stare one of the workers gave my daughter. Needless to say, I will never go here again.
author: Robert L.

description:
Mmmm...the tostada I ordered here was yummy. I should've asked for chicken but that's OK. All of the ingredients here are fresh and don't leave me with that gross too much grease feeling like I have at some traditional taquerias, that said, I like this place. Both locations have a friendly staff and they also offer a to die for rootbeer float that has Humphrey Slocombe ice cream in it!

They also offer a Super Baby Burrito which seems like an oxymoron. How can a burrito be super, yet baby at the same time? Oh well, it's filled with good stuff so who cares?

I'll be back...
author: Amy J.

description:
Ah Noe Valley, you always seem to have promise, but alas, you never fail to disappoint. I've known about this restaurant for a while, but was turned off to it because it is "Mexican inspired" food, not traditional. But I've embraced fusion restaurants in other forms, so I thought I could give TLC a chance. 

The mister and I tried the pozole rojo and the garlic shrimp burrito. The pozole looked beautiful with crunchy radishes and cabbage piled on top of the soup. It was desperately in need of being more sour and spicy, but I was provided with only one quarter of a lime. I know we're having a lime crisis right now, but I could have used a lemon! Or some other citrus/vinegar source. So I resorted to good ol' Tapatio to increase the spicy/sour level. The shrimp in the burrito was questionably fishy tasting, but I know the shrimp wasn't spoiled, it's just not a taste that I prefer to have in my shrimp. The burrito otherwise was a bit boring. I've had better at La Espiga De Oro or even El Toyonese. 

They do have a really great salsa bar and provide chips with your meal. The chips alone are terribly bland so they definitely need the salsa, which are all fresh and interesting. There are about 5-6 salsa options, plus pickled jalapenos. 

Otherwise, the food was pretty so so for me and they do have friendly service. I know TLC is not really about the food necessarily. It's more about the convenience of being in the neighborhood and how kid-friendly this place is. The food isn't bad at all and the ingredients are chosen with care, but I wouldn't return.
author: Victoria J.

description:
This is a true love hate relationship:
Love the local/ organic ingredients, the way they toast the tortilla and the salsa bar, the cashiers are always super nice, however there seems to be serious portion control issues and issue with deliverance of the ingredients inside their burritos. Sometimes On my last several visits I had a hard time finding steak or guacamole in my burrito or when I do its all crammed into the last inch of the burrito. 
If I hear back from someone at T.L.C. and they agree to work on this I will quickly change my rating to a 5, otherwise I don't know that I will go back.
author: Rob S.

description: Fantastic food. Very tasty and nothing like a typical taqueria. Interesting burritos besides the usual and the usual ones come in two sizes and with tortilla choices. Service is fantastic. A great crew.
author: Josh F.

description: Great food. The salsas are tasty and the burritos aren't packed with too much rice. The outside seating is nice too
author: Kat A.

description: This location is the worst! They have the rudest staff and do not know how to work a phone. I have been hung up on twice and then no one called me back. When I called 3 more times, there was no answer. Absolutely the WORST service I have ever received. I have also found hair in food, this place needs to be shut down! I wish there was a zero star option for this place.
author: Andrew H.

description:
This place is OK if you are stuck in Noe Valley and are desperate for Mexican food. Compared to the "real stuff" in Mission, which is only 10-15 min away, TLC has nothing on par with it.

The portions were small, the amount of meat to non-meat ratio in my burrito was comical, and there were limited ingredients for how much I paid. 

In stark contrast, for $8 dollars (which is about the same price TLC charges) I can get a "super burrito" at Taqueria Vallarta (on 24th st in Mission) that is 3X bigger than the baby burrito I got, which has 3 times more meat and has additional avocado slices and sour cream in addition to the beans & cheese that was already in the burrito. *AND* I can get it at Vallarta also with whole wheat wrap and sans rice (which I now do because I'm on a low-glucose diet) too! 

TLC does offer a wide variety of salsa that at first seems like a draw, but none of them were that interesting. Vallarta has 3-4 sauces as well and their orange spicy sauce is REALLY SPICY and AWESOME and MEMORABLE.

There are better things to eat in Noe Valley if you are stuck here for food.
author: Elizabeth T.

description:
Quick and honest service.
Decent portion. Flavorful.
Constantly great. Friendly staff.
Love the selection of salsa!!
author: Mac K.

description:
They have a lot of organic items available
The staff is super nice THE FLAVORS ARE GREAT 

A few tables are located outside in the back
Salsa bar has good 
Selections
author: Sheila F.

description:
Cali mex or just bland mex... tastes like someone found a recipe online and opened a restaurant. Had a carne asada burrito and my wife had chicken. Both had the same impressions. 

The place is clean and staff were ok but I cannot think of a reason to return.
author: Easwud C.

description:
Place is nice & clean. Friendly staff. Salsa bar is great. We had Ordered chicken verde enchiladas w black beans and rice.
&& Cheese enchilada and a guacomole enchilada. We also had plantain burrito which was unusually sweet and uncooked. 
The plates came out warm cheese hadn't even melted.., even after we asked for them heat them up they had this cubed cheese That still wouldn't melt. Very curious on what type of cheese it is.
author: Kat S.

description: Good Poole but a little bit spicy yo. Beware of you have bowel issues like I do. Excuse lil chihuahua is spicy af.
author: Brandon E.

description:
Tiny joint serving fresh Mexican fare.

Actually it's more CaliMex to me rather than authentic Mexican, not that it is a bad thing at all!  My friend recommended coming here since he eats here at least once a week since he lives close by.

Checked out the menu and they have burritos, quesedillas, enchiladas, tostada, and tacos.  Fairly typical menu for a Mexican restaurant.  For all the items, you get to choose a protein, and decided to go with the chili verde chicken, since that's not something I have too often!

For the burrito, it's not that big, although you can order it in 3 different sizes.  It comes with rice, pico de gallo, salsa, cabbage salad, and the choice of beans.  You can choose from 4 kind of beans, which is pretty great.  I'm not a fan of refried beans so I went for the vegetarian black beans.  Nice little plump black beans that's lightly seasoned!  The chili verde chicken is soft and tender, and goes really well with all the ingredients.  For some reason, the burrito just tasted really... fresh, even though with everything it sounds like it should be a heavy heavy meal!  They probably could've stuffed it a bit more but I guess that's reserved for the super burrito?  The regular burrito was enough for me though.

There's also a salsa bar with different salsas so for people that love variety, it's a great spot.  Tried all the salsas and they are all tasty, but my favorite was definitely the one with the tomatillo and used it on everything from my burrito to the free tortilla chips they serve!

Good spot for a casual meal!
author: Duke C.

description:
BRO. DO YOU EVEN MOUTHGASM?

Seriously though. Have you had the plantain burrito? 

Sweet mother of all that is good and pure in the world, there will be nothing else to describe the flavor profile of every bite. 

I wish you well.
author: Rosavida C.

description:
I wouldn't exactly call this place Mexican. I would say it is more Mex-American. While all the flavors are great and very fresh, this will not satisfy your craving for a real taqueria. 

I highly recommend the fried plantain burrito. ($11 or so) You wouldn't know that there is no meat in it if you eat it. Unless you are super hungry you can get away with sharing it along with some chips. 

The salsa bar is excellent as well with 5-6 different options to choose from.

A little expensive but delicious.
author: R I.

description: Pretty disappointed right now after hearing so much about the plantain burrito.  I called for a pick up order,  came to grab my burrito and I never saw any sour cream or cheese and to put the Cherry on top,  I didn't check the price in the menu and was shocked to find out that this burrito costs about 9 dollars but I was charged under 13 dollars.  Not sure what the extra charge was for,  but I won't be coming back to that disappointment again.  I didn't even get chips with my order so what did I pay for??
author: jacqueline g.

description: I see that I will be one of the few, if only, terrible reviews for this restaurant. So be it. I ordered my meal through DoorDash. Two enchiladas with rice & beans and a pint of salsa with a watermelon agua fresca. I requested that the salsa be spicy, and asked "If possible, can I have one red sauce and one green?" under special requests for the enchiladas. I received an email from Door Dash notifying me of a price increase from the restaurant to accommodate my special requests. It wasn't much. No big deal.... I receive my order less than 45 minutes later; yay, fast service! NO. No drink. There were two pint sized CONTAINERS.  One was full, spicy red salsa. The second one was filled to just under halfway with green salsa. No chips, and when paying for the in restaurant gratis salsa there was no indication that you had to ask for chips or even a way to order chips. Enchiladas were BOTH covered in red sauce........ FOOD WAS ICE COLD. I reheated it 3 times for a total of 4 minutes all together. The center wasn't warming up... It had been in the fridge. Mmmmmm..... Fresh! Let me eat this fresh hot meal with my giant containers of salsa.... Who needs chips? Icy beans can be used as hard chip like dipping tools! (Wait, was I up-charged for chips I didn't get, [which should have been included with the giant salsa I ordered unless otherwise stated] the zany & preposterous idea of 2 different enchilada sauces for 2 different enchiladas [I didn't get that either], or the drink I never received, or the time it took to spoon out my meal from the left overs in the fridge???, maybe it was for the burnt beyond recognition chunks of what I assume were the peppers & onions supposedly "stuffed" inside the enchiladas [they were plunked on top of the entire meal like someone took what they scraped off of the grill at the end of the night and slapped them over my ready to heat left overs). Once the food was heated up, it wasn't a damn 4-5 stars worth of delicious... Boring Tex mex with bland salsa flavors. Crap fest food
author: Erica K.

description:
I'm really depressed that I found this place my last week living in San Francisco.  Then again, I probably saved a whole bunch of money because I would have been eating at this place everyday if I had found it sooner.  The place is jammed packed like most places in SF that serve great food.  While I was here, I had the Al Pastor burrito and it was the bomb diggity. The meat was quality; it had that nice chew and it was POPPING with flavor.  What really got me about this place though was the tortilla they used for the burrito. It was far superior to any of the other tortillas I had seen at the 100+ burrito places in SF. Definitely makes a difference.

  If you're craving a burrito and you're in the Noe Valley (or SF in general), this is the place to get your fix.
author: Alex L.

description:
More mediocre mexican. 

this place is kind of typical - mediocre mexican. It's alright, but won't impress you.
author: Stephanie M.

description:
Have been eating here for last 5 years...at least 3 times a month... Have messed up my order only twice out of 600 odd times... That must say somethings abt this place
Expensive yes bad no... Never disappointed in 5 years except twice...
author: Amit K.

description:
Here's a fun game:  How many restaurant names created with real, pre-existing words, could you create that seemingly have nothing to do with food but would still entice people to come on in?  

I don't know what "Little Chihuahua" has to do with food, but I love dogs and happen to have a little one, so just seeing the signage here sort of makes me smile.  The fact that Broke-Ass Stuart also offered $20 worth of food for $10 meant it was a destination and, just like my little dog, that made me happy.  .
 
Little Chihuahua is a friendly, neighborhood place that serves fresh Mexican-ish food of the organic/sustainable/local sort.  They offer a great, clean, fresh salsa bar with 6 unique salsas to go with the nice big bowl of free chips they provide.  

You order at the counter and the gal there could not have been friendlier.  She steered J correctly to the popular "garlic shrimp burrito" and he was overjoyed:  A ton of shrimp swimming in a warm, garlicky bath along with spiced slaw and the usual fillings.  

I opted for the carne asada tostada salad and, while it didn't have a whole lot of meat, it was undeniably a good, fresh salad that veered more closely to California-Mexican fusion than a true tostada.  That's not a complaint though; it was pretty delicious.  

The tab for this (one beer, one burrito, one tostada salad, chips and salsa) rang up at just under $26 (not including my Broke-Ass coupon) which seemed high for a traditional taqueria but just fine for this pleasant, casual, family-friendly eatery.

A nice little find...  if I lived in the neighborhood I'd be here often.
author: Tracey A.

description: I'm a fan of Little Chihuahua. It's pretty similar to Papalote (another fav), but they have a salsa bar with a number of salsa options instead of just one (roasted tomato is the best!). This spot has a well lit, roomy dining area and the staff is friendly and efficient. Their garlic shrimp burrito is hard to beat and I like their whole wheat tortilla option.
author: Jeremy S.

description:
Normally I don't like chihuahuas, but I think I'll make an exception for this one! 

I absolutely LOVE how Little Chihuahua has a ton of options! Or maybe that's a bad thing since it takes me even longer to decide which combo to pick. Whole wheat tortilla with black beans? Spinach tortilla with chicken? Whatever, I guess it just means I have to keep coming back here to see what goes best together!

The concept of the "baby" burrito is great too! I've found that most burritos are HUGE, so it's nice to know Little Chihuahua provides a smaller version. I was actually able to finish a baby! Oh and it's kind of confusing, but to clear things up, the Super Baby burrito does NOT mean it's even smaller than the baby. It just means that it comes with sour cream, cheese, and guac!

The place is really clean and cozy feeling. They have these cute colorful cups for salsa and plates for the entrees. Colors = happiness!

Ouch for the extra side of guac costing $3.50 :T

I definitely need to try their specialty burritos! Fried plantain and black bean?! HELLooo! It'll be worth the $2 extra :)
author: Kei H.

description: The orange margarita was the best! So refreshing and Delicious! And the chips.... Oh my! Can't wait til my next visit.
author: Betsy R.

description:
Try Thee The Salmon Taco

If you like salmon, you are in for culinary bliss.

Avo lovers suggest add avo even though it comes with a lil guac spring for the extra avo.

Fine agave wine margaritas as well.
author: Foggy Daze D.

description: I've tried a variety of different menu items and have never been pleased, the best you'll get is passable. The verde salsa isn't very good and the prices are high. This place is much more convenient for me, but I'l still pass it in favor of Casa Mexicana every time.
author: Thomas P.

description:
The tortilla soup, full of chicken, queso, and avocado was delicious. Seriously, I couldn't stop eating it. 

Service was quick and we easily found an open table, but the place got crowded pretty quickly after our arrival.
author: Ashley M.

description:
Plantain and black beans together in a burrito? ohhh yeah!! My mouth is watering just remembering that taste! It is a reason to go back to little chihuahua someday. 

We also had the Burrito pastor with pork, which was also good but not as yummy as the vegetarian. 

Their chips and variety of salsas is excellent even though I missed the classic green salsa you can find in the other taquerias. The habanero salsa was pretty tasty.

Horchata was without a doubt a great refreshing liquid to enjoy with my burrito.

All together it was a wonderful snack for a relaxing evening around Noe Valley.
author: Alex R.

description: From my 5 year old son:  I love the burritos, wrapped up with salad on the side and salsa.
author: Kim H.

description:
I'm a huge fan of their tacos and there's plenty of seating at this location. As much as I love El Farolito, when it comes to carne asada tacos, Little Chihuahua takes the cake. 

GET:
- Carne Asada Tacos: $5 is pretty steep for a taco BUT they're big and since it comes with 2 tortillas per taco, there's always enough meat to split 1 taco into 2. So basically you're getting 2 tasty tacos for the price of 1! The meat is also seasoned way better than El Farolito's. 
- the dark green salsa. Fresh with a spicy kick. Love!
- If you want to detox after work, the sangria and margarita are both good options  

SKIP:
- Nachos; they give you chips and they have a huge selection of salsa so no need
- All the other salsas.
author: Vivian N.

description:
The grass-fed carne asada tastes like filet mignon! 

The guacamole is ALMOST as good as my homemade guac; and as a guac champion that's saying a lot. 

The nachos are massive and delicious.

This is my favorite fresh Mex spot so far in SF.
author: Michelle P.

description:
A decent burrito place located in the middle of Noe Valley.   After coming here a couple times, I decided to write about the food that I have had here.

Plantain Burrito:  I would come back here just for this.  I have yet to find another place that serves plantain burrito.  The plantains were caramelized and oozing out of the burrito.  This made it a little sweet and salty which was amazing.  If you are a vegetarian, I would highly suggest getting this burrito.  (Definitely a lot better than a bean and cheese one)

Shrimp Burrito: Does not compare to El Farolito's Carne Asada and Shrimp Burrito but it did its job in filling up my stomach.  This would be a decent burrito if it didn't face such stiff competition

Pozole:  Lots of pozole and enough meat.  The soup was super hearty and I couldn't finish it.  The meat was fall off the bone tender.  This comes with a couple corn tortilla.

Child Taco Meal:  I was feeling a bit peckish and wanted something light.  A child's taco meal came with 1 taco (really  meat on top of a small quesadilla), a bowl of black beans and some rice.  If you are looking for a light meal for not too much $$, this would be a great choice.

PS: Meals comes with free chips and the green salsa here is amazing.
author: Jessica P.

description: I have been a long-time fan of The Little Chihuahua, so when my now husband and I decided to get married, we reached out to see if the Little Chihuahua offered a taco bar. Lucky for us, they did! Michael from the Little Chihuahua was wonderful to work with and met with us in person at the 24th street location to go over logistics; we got to try all the different taco fillings, salsas and aguas frescas to figure out what which options to pick. Michael was very easy to work with and put my mind at ease about how things would go day of, which is key to your mental health when you are planning a wedding. Day-of, they did not disappoint! All my friends and family loved the chips, salsa and guacamole bar they setup during cocktails, and the elaborate taco bar and taco salad buffet. I have a family full of foodies who are very particular about their food (we did our rehearsal dinner at Greens) and everyone raved about how good the food was, something you often don't get at weddings. We have friends who are vegetarian, gluten free, etc. and we realized a taco bar is for everyone, no matter what your dietary restrictions! Finally (and this was key for us), it's extremely affordable. I think you could probably order everything option on the catering menu for around $30 per person, which is unheard of for wedding in San Francisco for such high-quality food. Thank you Michael and team for being so amazing! I strongly encourage anyone looking for exceptional food for their wedding and a lovely staff to use the Little Chihuahua! And, as my husband says, for our anniversary, we can grab take out from them and head to our wedding venue (Stern Grove) for a picnic to relive the big day!
author: Kara A.

description: We got into our place pretty late upon arriving to town and we decided to walk around the neighborhood to see if we could find a bite to eat. We were jonesing for some tacos and came upon Little Chihuahua. It's a super casual spot; you order at the counter, grab your drinks and extras and your food comes to you in a few minutes. The al pastor tacos were ridiculous and I would stop here again for a quick bite.
author: Joshua C.

description: I come here for their tostada salads-which are huge. I usually split them with my co-worker when we're both craving something semi-healthy. It's way too big for one person to finish. Their garlic shrimp burrito is really good too. I saw an article that they were known for their plantain burrito and thought that was a nice change in the burrito industry. I asked about it one day and the lady at the register let me put some of those plantains in my shrimp burrito. It wasn't bad at all. One star off for prices. I guess in Noe Valley, rent is expensive so merchants have to charge more. Ahh, the price of living in San Francisco...
author: Laura T.

description:
Oh my heavens! 

As I was standing outside reading the menu and a nice guy 
walks out and says "get the SALMON tacos hands down!" 
and hops on his motorbike (with what was probably his own
salmon tacos..)

Thank you sir, for your advice! 

I'm so hungry just thinking about them right now! DELICIOUS!!!!! 
Big chunks of fresh Salmon... so so yummy.

Also, tried the Tostada Salad and Verde Chicken Enchiladas. A++

A few things I like about this place are:
-the ingredients are high-quality (they don't use cheap iceberg
lettuce, yay!) 
-the tortilla's aren't thin and don't fall apart on you
-their various salsa's are e-x-c-e-l-l-e-n-t! 
-portion sizes are generous!

I think this is another place for me to empty my wallet on, seeing
how its in the neighborhood... Eeeek!
author: S. M.

description:
The Little Chihuahua has been on my list of local places to try for ages -- particularly because it has consistently better Yelp reviews than my other neighborhood haunt. I finally stopped in last week, and while my burrito was good, for the price ($8.25-9.25, + $1.75 for canned soda) it winds up being more expensive than Casa Mexicana. 

I had a chicken (pollo asado) burrito, and the service was lovely -- I came in (just for takeout) about 20 minutes prior to closing, and they were really nice and friendly. The ingredients in the burrito were fresh, and the chicken was of good quality, but nothing was overly flavorful. It wasn't bad, per se, it just wasn't that delicious, filling meal you expect when you're craving a burrito. That said, I would come back and give it another shot.
author: Katie M.

description:
It was our last night in Noe Valley and we wanted to make it a quiet one. Rather than dining at a restaurant, we opted for take out at The Little Chihuahua (TLC) and brought it back to our rental. 

It was 9:15pm, TLC closes at 10pm, and we were 30 mins away. All of us took out our smartphones, perused the menu (we read the menu out loud for the driver, of course), and placed our order over the phone. We arrived 15 minutes of placing the order and our food was ready for pick up. That's quick service!

We had a big order and was half expecting to have something missing, but it was perfect! The portions were huge and food delicious. The chips we ordered for sharing was still warm when we got back to the house. 

Added a few bottles of Cab that we purchased in Napa and it was the perfect way to end the night.
author: Lily C.

description:
Much needed relief from taqueria Mexican this place offers a unique menu and a break from Mission style ambiance.

This is my go-to place in Noe, especially after being very disappointed with Barney's across the street.

Get the garlic shrimp burrito or the tostada salad (an actual real salad!)
author: Brian H.

description:
Little dog is pretty good.  Not the most authentic, but I like that they have good veggie options and whole wheat tortillas.  PLEASE PLEASE PLEASE GET VEGAN CHEESE!!!! I recently found out I can't have dairy and was surprised to learn that LC doesn't have vegan cheese.  I need cheezy goodness on my burritos, y'all!

And yeah, it's stroller/screaming child town for sure.  DO NOT GO AT 5 PM ON A FRIDAY unless you want to experience the best birth control ever.
author: Jessica M.

description:
The Good:   Great Ameri-mexican food.  There is a very wide choice of Americanized, healthy-ized fresh Mexican food that is actually very tasty.  There are lots of great choices for someone on a gluten-free diet.  The Tostada Salads, Enchiladas and Pozole Rojo are my favorites.  

The Not So Good:  Unfortunately, this is a popular destination for infants, toddlers, small children and the young parents who created them.  So just be aware your dining experience will include screaming babies, crying toddlers, noisy children, scolding fathers and nursing mothers (and lots of high-end strollers blocking everything).  But hey, its Noe Valley.
author: Matt S.

description:
I was astonished by how bad the food was.

(1) I ordered the chilaquiles, described as allowing you to choose the way you want the eggs cooked.  I asked for poached eggs.  The staff could not handle this request; did not understand what poached eggs are or how to make them; and served me fried eggs instead.

If you're in the business of serving breakfast, and you invite guests to choose how they want their eggs cooked, you should not be thrown by a request for poached eggs.

(2) The "chilaquiles" dish is described as having eggs, sour cream, and cheese on top of fried tortilla chips that were "tossed in a roasted poblano pepper sauce."

The chips weren't "tossed" in the sauce.  They were soaked until they were completely soggy, wet, and, what's worse, COLD.  No crunch at all.  The starchy substance in the sauce was not recognizable as tortilla chips.

If they had applied warm sauce to warm chips right before serving, it could have been great, but, alas, as it was, it was inedible.  I literally could not eat most of the soggy, cold, mushy dish.

(3) Finally --- and this is a little complaint -- I couldn't locate any cheese on the dish.

I've heard their breakfast burritos are good, but I recommend avoiding the chilaquiles.
author: Victoria P.
