description: Chicken super burrto..loaded with salsa....and a tomato tortilla....perfect with my old friend....coca cola....this is dinner..
author: Eric C.

description: Great fresh Mexican fare in convenient location.  Love the watermelon aqua Fresca, enchiladas and tostada salad.  Great for families with children too and takeout!
author: Dave C.

description:
Despite using very fresh ingredients and having reasonably attractive plate presentation, the food here is universally flavorless. It is obvious that those preparing the food here never taste it before it goes to the customer.

Here's the one immutable truth of cooking: It your dish is packed with flavorful ingredients such as cheese, carnitas, red sauce, peppers, etc; and it's still bland, you haven't seasoned it properly.

TASTES LIKE NOTHING DESPITE A TRUCKLOAD OF FLAVORFUL INGREDIENTS? SALT IS THE ANSWER!!!! It's just that simple.

It's a shame because the people here are courteous and the restaurant is new and clean.

Noe Valley still has room for a great taqueria and until TLC can find the saltshaker, I'll continue to drive to Dos Pinas in the SOMA.
author: Christopher H.

description: my fave neighborhood joint... excellent chorizo, salsas
author: James L.

description: Had the Shrimp Burrito. I thought I wasn't hungry but gobbled the entire thing up - so yummy! Highly recommend!
author: Karina S.

description:
People really seem to love this place, it's always busy and I've heard nothing but good things through word of mouth, but I just don't get it. 

Sure, the salsa bar is well stocked, but salsa bars are fairly common. I ordered the Steak Burrito and was sorely disappointed. The tortilla was tough and the meat tasted sweet and tomato-y, more akin to bits of steak smothered in ketchup than traditional Mexican food. 

I say, skip it, save your money and walk the .5 miles to the Mission for a better burrito.
author: Nan H.

description:
Image: 4 out of 10
Level of cleanliness: 4 out of 10
Menu versus execution: 7 out of 10
Condition of facilities and setup: 6 out of 10
Customer service: 7 out of 10
Atmosphere: 6 out of 10
Pricing: 7 out of 10
Other yelpers rate accuracy: 2 out of 10

In my opinion, this place has been grossly  overrated by other yelpers.

This place is a semi-fancy taqueria that claims to serve organic products. It looks, though, very grim and it smells like old, dirty San Francisco underground café. The place is cold in every way--no heating system working and no feeling of welcoming customers present at all. The place also has extremely low lighting (I wondered what it is that they didn't want me to notice). Their kitchen is visibly super clean, but the rest of the taqueria isn't. Dirty seats and tables (with crumbs of chips all over them) and super dirty floors...and walls (typical of San Francisco, pig town by excellence). Gross! I'm glad I didn't have to go to the restroom there this time.

I was immediately shocked by their limited variety of non-alcoholic bottled drinks. That's a big minus for a Noe Valley taqueria!

As I busily cleaned my bench and table from all the chip crumbs left by the previous customers, I took a good look at a nasty-looking soup just served to my neighboring eaters. I asked them what it was, and they told me it was a tortilla soup. It looked terrible, like cheap broth with added grilled chicken and tortilla chips thrown in it. Tortilla soup is supposed to be a slow food dish; it actually is considered a fancy dish in Mexico, not a fast food improvised broth with chips! But the person eating it told me it wasn't bad. She seemed to know what she was talking about; I had a chance to briefly chat with her and her friend about food and places to go.

After being freaked out by the non-authentic appearance of the tortilla soup, I became quickly aware I was not in a Mexican restaurant but rather in a semi-fancy taqueria. So, in order to test the waters, I ended up having a chicken enchilada with green sauce; it included rice, mini-salad, and pinto beens on the side. I wasn't mesmerized by the texture quality of the enchilada (fast-food preparation is not the right way of making enchiladas) and the chicken had the texture of...average taqueria chicken meat. But I was overall pleasantly surprised by the authenticity of the enchilada flavor, especially its green sauce--surprisingly good and authentic. The side beans were also surprisingly authentic--cooked longer than just one hour, properly and simply seasoned. The rice had a Mexican fonda consistency and flavor (natural tomato seasoned, dry, slightly overcooked red rice), which is still passable.

So, as far as the enchiladas with side rice and beans go, they do have an authentic Mexican flavor, which truly surprised me. But the level of cleanliness and the super low lighting was like a bad sign, like a very red flag. Should this place be considered fancy just because it serves organic? Does it really serve organic? I'd rather dine non-organic authentic Mexican than organic Mexican cooked for people who can't tell the difference between authentic and non-authentic.

I believe this place should improve its lighting and cleanliness, specialize more on tacos and burritos, and exclude dinner dishes that are, by Mexican tradition, supposed to be prepared with plenty of time and devotion.

I will come back here only if I have to. Today, I had to, because nothing else around was open at 10 pm.
author: Raymond F.

description:
Went here for brunch and really enjoyed it!  Don't order with your eyes though - the portions are large and you won't be able to finish especially while munching on their yummy chips and salsa.

Si, si, si!
- The salsa bar rocks!  I liked them all expect for the habenero, it had too much citrus and made me pucker with each taste.
- Passion fruit mimosa, mmm!
- Didn't expect their coffee to be that flavorful, but was pleasantly surprised.
- The service was very friendly.

No, no, no!
- Wish there was less of a vinegar taste in their Mexican potatoes (or was it in their Ranchero sauce?)
- The back patio would be a great area if they fixed it up and added more seats.
- Their chilaquiles, while tasty enough, isn't very authentic so don't be surprised.
author: Vicente G.

description:
Yummy salmon tacos. Very tasty grilled veggi nachos. Delicious agave wine margaritas. 

Clean pleasant location in Noe Valley. 

Highly recommend this delicious spot for semi-gourmet mexican fare.
author: Evrett K.

description:
Wow so disappointed - Was a regular here, however, came in Sunday evening to have an extremely disappointing experience. Cold burritos we originally had to send back. And now the next day - half our group is experiencing food poisoning. We can in at 9:30 pm (closing is at 10)...granted that is late but don't take our money if you don't want to serve till then. (There was a handful of people after we came in too) ...

For customers who were regular every week...we will now not be back or recommending it to others. A big bummer.
author: Grace M.

description:
Went on a Groupon, if I hadn't I'd be mad.  I have wanted to try this place for over a year, so I jumped at the Groupon. We ordered the mushroom enchiladas (they were served cold) and the tostada salad with Carnitas.  The Salad was just eh, not enough dressing, too many peppers, the cucumbers were sliced into too big chunks.  Just not my favorite tostada. 

I will say that they acknowledge they are not a mexican place but "mexican influenced" so good for them by being honest.  

The chips and salsa bar was good though.
author: Amy W.

description: Great food and great service. I was hella hungry and looking for a new place to eat. This is definitely the best place for Mexican food in Noe Valley. I ordered the al pastor and burrito and customized it by adding pinto beans instead of black beans. The burrito was totally delicious. There was mango and pineapple salsa inside. It greatly counter acted the meat and saltiness. It made me full and satisfied, would absolutely come back!
author: Dan G.

description:
After a disappointing and expensive experience at Saru down the street, my friend and I found this place. We were still hungry, so we were like "hey, why not?"

Gordo's can go suck it cuz The Little Chihuahua is now my new burrito love spot! 

Food: 

Garlic Shrimp Burrito - Sautéed shrimp, avocado, rice,
black beans, smoky chile salsa, pico de gallo, garlic
salsa, cilantro & onion. Wasn't dry and had a really good consistency. 

Mexican Coke

Chips - very crispy, fresh and its complimentary if you dine in. There is also a salsa bar with a fresh variety of salsas. Pico De Gallo and Chipotle sauces ftw!


Service:

I'm surprised the guy memorized our orders when he brought us our orders of food. 

Overall:

Very satisfied since I'm actually full! Will come back again if I'm in the area. xD
author: Jason C. J.

description:
what i ordered... super burrito w/ carnitas

i ordered and paid for a super and i got me a regular burrito, i already ate half of it before i noticed but knowing me i would never return or complain(in person) unless it was at an utmost importance. burrito was so-so.... it tasted more like a stringy al pastor than carnitas, maybe because of the almost fajita like sauce and the pork's dried not crispy texture, though the rice filling was well seasoned and cooked right.

complementary chips were good and with variety of good tasting sauces to choose from at the condiment counter

(the place was weird, was filled but with not a single brown person inside besides of the cooks and the bussers)

ambiance... good (traditional with a twist, condiment's and utensils were clean and well stocked)
service... good (cashier was all smile)
cost... $+ (expensive)
author: Gors P.

description:
Little Chihuahua had become something of a staple for me over the last few months. While it might not be the most authentic of Mexican restaurants (not that it claims to be), it is surely a delicious one, and really it's their more unique offerings that do it for me. In particular, the salmon tacos are stupendously awesome (we're talking ultra mega good, here), as is the black bean/plantain burrito.  I generally use it for takeout, but they've got ample seating as well and beer on tap if you want to sit down.

The ambiance is welcoming, the staff is friendly, the service is fast.  What's not to like?
author: Stuart E.

description: Great tasting Mexican food at reasonable prices.  My first experience (a take out) was excellent, and I will surely come back for their delicious burritos and mushroom quesadillas in the future.  GREAT habanero salsa too! I'll be back!
author: Andy S.

description:
I started going to Little Chihuahua for their plantain burritos (excellent vegetarian burrito!) but recently started eating their taco salad. It is excellent and includes a mangos, black beans, and a light queso fresco along with the usual taco salad toppings. It is a large portion with high quality ingredients which I think corresponds to the "a little pricier than your average taqueria" menu.

Beyond being an excellent salad the service at this Little Chihuahua is prompt and friendly and the restaurant is very clean. Great salsa bar too. It isn't too busy at lunch time besides some kids and parents/nannies.
author: Leuwam T.

description: Love this place! Not authentic, but delicious food with a great salsa bar.  Definitely a gem.
author: Ghizal A.

description: Set up like a taqueria but has grassfed beef and their carnitas are killer. Dude at the register is super nice and the facilities are clean. Also has a good variety in their salsa bar.
author: Michelle R.

description: I just had the most horrible pastor burrito ever. It was bland and flavorless; for a pastor burrito that is just crazy. I have had heartburn all day, never again. I am surprised by all the four star reviews. Check out San Jalisco. Now that is how Mexican food should taste like ..
author: Moy V.

description: Didn't really have a craving for Mexican, but upon being convinced, I decided to try it out. The pasole TOTALLY brought me back home to the experiences of my childhood and made my day!
author: Courtney L.

description: Food is fine, nothing remarkable. But don't think this is a high-throughout burrito joint like you'll find down the hill in the Mission.  They are slow, it took them 15 min+ to make a burrito to go on a Saturday afternoon.
author: philip k.

description: Amazing shrimp burrito and carne Asada burrito! The staff is so friendly! The salsa is amazing! My favorite is the spicy chipotle and my friend is obsessed with the tomatillo verde salsa. Wow I'm definitely coming back and I recommend this place to anyone! They even have "baby burritos" for the small stomached folks and kids!
author: Jenni A.

description:
THESE PORTIONS ARE HUGE! 

I have been here twice and both times have been super satisfied and happy. Oh, FULL too!! I ordered a salad while my boyfriend ordered a burrito, and we ate for four. It was awesome. Everything was super fresh, big portioned, and filled me up. And I eat A LOT. Like, this is no exaggeration.
author: Alanna P.

description: One of the best places to grab food in Noe (not too much competition there).  Really nice staff.  Quality ingredients.  I could do without the heavy medal they play at lunch time.
author: kate l.

description:
The food here is definitely not very authentic but it is pretty good as long as you are aware of that before hand. 
I mean they put cabbage in the burrito, which I thought is strange but kind of nice, I can not really decide.  
Any who, the space is cute and clean.  It is also very cozy.  Don't plan on going with a group.  
Unfortunately, this very San Francisco hipster style place is over priced.  For the food being just okay, I would prefer for it to be less expensive.
OH! and the salsa.....not awesome..... :(
author: Jessica S.

description:
When I was a kid, family home taco night was my favorite meal. You know: the bowls filled with shredded cheese, shredded lettuce, finely chopped onion, the plastic container of sour cream with a spoon in it, the glass container of Pace Picante (NEW YORK CITY!?!?), and the ground beef with a pack of Lawry's taco seasoning. My mom, being the best mom ever (no offense to yours) would pan fry the corn tortillas and sprinkle them with parmesan cheese a la Jimboy's Sacramento. The flour tortillas (also pan fried) would be light brown and crispy, and an utter delight.

I recall this story because I am convinced that Mexican food - whether it is gringo (which anything involving Lawry's clearly is) or not - is the most fun, delicious, accessible, unboring food around. I could eat it everyday...and I could also eat at Little Chihuahua everyday.

Their food is fresh, wholesome and delicious. All their meat is organic. They have a salsa bar filled with amazing choices. Their chips are light and crispy. I have tried the tacos, burritos and dinner platters and they are all on point!

If you have guests in town, need a quick meal for the kids, just worked out and need some fuel, or just want a yummy familial taco night, get thee to Little Chihuahua on 24th!
author: Serena Q.

description: This was a disappointing meal. This place was recommended to me as a vegetarian, but it didn't quite hit the mark. The super burrito was mostly beans with barely any guac, sour cream or cheese. They had the option to add vegetables to it, but that's not what I'm after when I go for Mexican food. The chips were not authentic tasting and the salsa was kinda sour. I couldn't even drink my "margarita" which was more of an orange flavored wine cooler and was too bitter, salty and sweet all at once. It is along the lines of Papalote in attempted style, but the flavor doesn't come close. Sorry, little chihuahua (and my taste buds).
author: Andrea F.

description: Had the fried plantain black bean specialty burrito and it was amazing!  While I picked it because it just sounded intriguing, it totally surprised me with how tasty it was. Well balanced flavors for a burrito too which is always important. It's now one of my favorite vegetarian burritos! Could easily split the burrito size and save half for another meal or share with someone. Chips were also delicious with a solid salsa bar. Service was quick and friendly. (More expensive than your normal Mission burrito, but worth it in my opinion and being in Noe you kind of have to know food will cost more...)
author: Tiffany W.

description:
I believe this place is better than Nicks Tacos. =X

I love the way they make their tacos, especially the Salmon/Carnitas/Carne Asade. Every ingredient nicely compliments each other. 

The tostada is amazing!! I had it togo and when I brought it back home, it took my bf and I a good hour and a half to dig through. There was so much going on. If you ever feel like you are vegetable deprived, just order this salad and you'll feel much better about yourself.

My roommate and i tried their chocolate and tequila ice cream. Lets just say the tequila ice cream IS REALLY TEQUILA. I believe you can get a little tipsy lol.

Can't wait to come back!
author: Dor C.

description: overpriced and not great.  sad to say.  food just isn't up to par with other Mexican places in sf
author: Jordan S.

description:
Over the last two years, the Little Chihuahua has become my go-to, staple restaurant in San Francisco. I plan on moving out-of-state in the next year, and I often lament how I will survive without it. 

The food is why. It's always made with fresh ingredients. (If you need recommendations: I often get the Al Pastor Tacos or the Carnitas Quesadilla.) In addition to the flavor, TLC is a meal that you can feel good about. The ingredients are healthy, and with some portion-control you can leave without ingesting 1000 calories.
Overall, the service here is friendly, and the restaurant is always clean. 

Best taqueria in the city.
author: Greg B.

description: The food sucked. I ordered cheese enchiladas and the cheese was not melted, they used the wrong type of cheese and the sauce was no good. While I like the idea of fresh organic mexican, this place is lacking in flavor. They need to rework their dishes if they want to stay open. I don't see this place lasting long. It's easy to get it right by adding the right flavors and salt. The service was pretty bad too. I will not be going back.
author: LuLu M.

description: TLC is great for a night you want to eat quickly with the family. Good burritos -garlic shrimp is the best- and my kids love their bean burritos. Service is fast and polite, and the sangria is good. It's a predictably easy and good dinner.
author: Sarah B.

description:
LC serves up my very favorite chicken tortilla soup.  Combining fresh veggies, fresh avo, and a healthy dose of spice, this soup quite simply rocks.  They even manage to make a "to go" version that doesn't end up soggy.  

LC also sports great guac, amazing salsa bar, and an impressive bottled beer selection including Session stubbies imported from Portland.
author: Melissa Y.

description:
This spot has had so many different incarnations...but Little Chihuahua has settled in and seems to be digging its claws into the ground.  It's the perfect casual, kid-friendly restaurant for Noe Valley.

I appreciate their casual vibe and the fact that they go out of their way to make families feel welcome.  There's plenty of stroller room, an abundance of high-chairs, kid-loving employees...it's the go-to place for nannies and stay-at-home parents alike. 

When I first tried Little Chihuahua, I remember trying to push our stroller through their door and having a very challenging time.  Without hesitation, the woman behind the counter jumped to my aid and held it open for me.  I thought that was very kind of her.  

The next week, I arrived for lunch and saw that the entire door had been replaced with a friendlier, ADA compliant door.  Obviously, the owners are proactive about  making improvements to their establishment that will ultimately welcome the entire neighborhood.  Kudos to them.

That said, I love their watermelon frescas and carnitas quesadillas.  Muffin tops developing on my midsection because of said frescas and quesadillas?  Not so much.
author: Kristina R.

description: I stopped by on my way home from work on 4th of July. Nothing else was open so I decided to give it a try. I ordered a chicken burrito with no salsa to go. I got home and two bites in realized it had salsa. I gave it away to my roommate then went back to get another one. I ordered very explicitly NO SALSA. The cashier assured me there would be no salsa. Get home, take a bite and there's even more salsa than the first one. I spent 20$ on two mistakes. Won't be going back
author: Jed A.

description: If you're from Sacramento or have ever eaten at Dos Coyotes it is basically the same thing, but probably not quite as good because I thought my al pastor was a little bit too sweet. I'd go back thought. My rating is 3 stars.
author: urban r.

description:
I'm not going to be too critical of my neighborhood taqueria (yes, I'm one of those annoying noe valley persons, but I still have a good palate!), so I'm going to play up my praise of the tortilla soup. In college, I worked at a place outside of Chicago where the cooks made crazy good tortilla soup. And, there used to be another place, one of the Mi Lindo... restaurants on 24th that is no longer that also had a brilliant tortilla soup-- 

So, finally, I've found my local tortilla soup replacement. The tortilla soup here is rich, meaty with chicken and has a lot of fun surprises like queso fresco, avo chunks, roasted corn, pico de gallo and fresh herbs. However, the main ingredient, tortillas, is the star! Chihuahua's tortilla chips are excellent: light, with a little salt and thin (delgado) with nice crunch. They're better than Papalotes tortilla chips! Sorry Papalote, but for a while now your chips taste stale all the time! 

Anyway, tortilla chips are what make tortilla soup. Some recipes for the soup require that you grind corn tortillas into the soup to thicken it but I don't think they do that at Chihuahua. Instead they add corn and give you lots of chips that will sink and soften as you eat. There's also a nice hit of spice somewhere in there. So, five full OLE's for their soup.

I'm also crazy about the Mexican Chocolate Humphrey Slocombe ice cream they carry. It's really spicy! But, in a good, complimenting way.

Sometimes there's too much cheese, often there's way too many onion slices in things (can they just cut back, a little?), but otherwise, everything always tastes fresh and the agua frescas are super tasty. 

I also like a taqueria with mommy cocktails and beer on tap. Nice job, Chihuahua. Just one of the many fans in the neighborhood. Shout out to all the talkative and endearing counter peeps! :)
author: E L.

description:
Fried Plantain & Black Bean Burrito, the best!!
I usually avoid black beans in case they are bland and rarely choose a vegetarian option over meat but fried plantains in a burrito sounded interesting. I was not disappointed, the burrito is sweet and savory with a little smokey spice. Highly recommend giving it a try.
author: Alison F.

description:
I came in here with two friends awhile back, and we've rarely gone one weekend without returning. The main reason? Horchata. Seriously good stuff.

This spot also has a great vibe. It feels kind of like a coffee shop that serves Mexican food. The artwork is awesome, and the music rocks. 

The food isn't the best Mexican I've had in SF, but it's not bad. I prefer the enchiladas over the burritos. They have a nice salsa bar, too.

The environment is the main reason I keep showing up here. I'm always happy to come back =)
author: Caitlin W.

description:
Little Chihuahua, I want to like you. I really do. You're clean. You're cute. You have lots of cute bowls full of cute salsas. You like in a nice hood.
Sadly, little C, you are tasteless. I've tried your burritos, your stew, your tacos, your tostadas and you are consistently not that good. Oh, and you cost about twice as much as a good taqueria.
So perhaps we're just not meant to be.
author: Fred A.

description:
Thought I would  try their brunch and the food was  just ok.
Doubt i would go back though. Staff is nice and helpful  but didnt like that
someone brought 2 LARGE dogs onto patio  through the back  gate

Guess i expected more for the price
author: kavin m.

description: Better than it looks from the outside. Good food, quality ingredients and great salsa bar.
author: Antonia T.

description: It was a decent burrito. The salsas were good and added much needed flavor to the carne asada burrito I got. This might sound like blasphemy, but I might just pick Chipotle next time.
author: Anwar H.

description:
I have been coming here for a few years now, and it seem these past few months they have hired some really incompetent people. Especially the guy who worked there tonight wearing a shirt with cucumber text on it. Your a douche bag. When I walked into the restaurant this guy gave me a sideways look, as if I had walked in with my tongue sticking out of my mouth spouting religious non-sense. You work the cash register at Little chihuahua dude, wearing clothes not suited for a really nice taqueria, get  some collared shirts. Either way I really appreciate how you had me sitting down for a good 3-5 minutes before you gave me my food that was sitting right there on the counter. Sorry if you don't like short mexican dudes, though I can't help it. 

This is also the 3rd or 4th time in a row I have asked for no guacamole.....and low and behold I get.....guacamole. The only reason I don't make the trek to Taqueria Guadalajara on mission and Onandaga is because its a crucial trek, though I dont get any attitude and I get way better food AND they have lengua!!!
author: Mike C.

description:
I was so excited when this restaurant moved into Noe, based upon thumbs up reviews from friends about their Divis location.  After I tried the food, it took the edge off my excitement.  Many of the taste combos lack a flavorful kick -- the burrito fillings in particular.  And give us single girls a break -- I don't always have a pal to share -- why is your specialty plantain burrito only available in the large size?

On the flip side, agave margaritas are big, cheap, unique, and super-tasty.  Tortilla soup is delicious and with a subtle broth base, lots of veggies, chicken and fresh avocado.  Service is quick and courteous.
author: Cathy A.

description:
Wow... Really? That was my reaction when I found out that me and my friend paid 23 bucks on a rice burrito. I'm not kidding, $23 for a burrito a little larger than my phone with rice and tomatoes in it. Here is the full picture:

My friend and I walked in at 9:30 hungry and ready to try these "garlic shrimp burritos" that everybody on yelp seemed to like so much. The counter lady was nice and took our orders. Since they were going to close soon we decided to have them to go so that we can get out of their way. My friend likes simple (but boring) burritos. She just wanted shrimp, salsa, beans and rice. Simple right? I wanted everything on mine. Simple again right? WRONG. First the guy cooking seemed to be confused by my friend's order, how do I know this? Because I heard him ask the woman at the counter questions in Spanish and then him and another cook laugh at my friend's order. I ignore this because I then hear her correct him on the order, so I think well the cooks are jerks but at least we will get our food right. WRONG my friends, so very wrong. We get our burritos, I thank her and head home. We get home at 9:55 and unwrap our mini burritos. First Bite: Rice(but hey that happens sometimes) Second Bite: Rice Third Bite: Rice and tomatoes. Seriously? My friend opens up her burrito revealing rice and salsa. I'm serious, She paid 11+ bucks for rice and salsa. So I open mine, I have rice, salsa, avocado and about 3 shrimps. That's it.. I was pissed to say the least. How can you serve that to somebody? I felt so bad that I recommended this place to eat at that I knew I had to come here to warn everybody else. On yelp all the pictures and reviews looked so good but what we experienced was far from good. My friend ended up throwing hers away. 

So please, If you are hungry for some true Hispanic food look elsewhere, go to the mission, or go anywhere else for that matter! If you must eat there, please order to eat there, that way you can say something right then and there. Don't go home and be disappointed like I was. If i could rate 0 or negative stars, I would.
author: Gomez D.

description: If you become a regular like me then you will pretty much have sampled everything on the menu. My favorites are the garlic shrimp burrito, chicken tostada salad, chicken tortilla soup, sangria and watermelon juice. If you are lucky to work nearby, you may even qualify for their local merchant discount too.
author: Cheryl S.

description:
Two words - Salmon Tacos . . . . . and then everything else.

Love this little Mexican comfort food restaurant. On the edge of Noe Valley, a great place to have lunch while visiting the neighborhood.

Also a quiet little patio area in the back, or up front for ideal people-watching.
author: Dirk W.

description:
Fresh & tasty burritos, salads, and soups.  Really nice employees, good service.

Sadly inedible chilaquiles -- by the time the dish arrived at my table, it was a soggy, gloppy, unappetizing mess of wet chip mush, underdone eggs, and crema.  Meh.  Goo central.  Disappointing waste of $10.
author: Heather P.

description: Meal came out cold. Three of 4 of our diners have food poisoning today. Servers were not helpful or professional. I'm taking this place OFF our dining choices after having gone there a number of times.
author: Tom M.

description:
Checked this one off my list of restaurants to try. Good salsa bar!

It's just alright.
author: Andrea D.

description:
Papalote, you have some serious competition way on the OTHER side of 24th Street. They couldn't have been open more than a year or so but in that short time they are now my favorite place to eat in Noe Valley. Unfortunately they are so tucked away on 24th Street past Castro you might have missed them. I have never had a bad meal there and the place is well decorated, clean and the employees are friendly and prompt. For Mexican restaurants in this city there needs to be some middle ground in between the low-end shithole taquerias and the fancy-schmancy places. This is one of those places.

This is really tasty Mexican food at an affordable price in a neighborhood not known for catering to  quick, price-conscious eaters. Although Papalote basically does the same thing (and has incredible chips and salsa) I give this place the nod. Papalote can become very crowded, noisy, messy and over-populated with hipsters. This place never feel like that. I really need to try out the original one on Divisadero. 

Thank you for opening in the neighborhood an I hope you open a few more too.
author: Dave B.

description: Came here for the breakfast burrito after reading about it in some publication. Wasn't impressed as I found the spice blend to be a bit overpowering. I found myself enjoying the food less and less as I progressed through the burrito. Tables were pretty dirty but I enjoyed the casual nature of the place. I appreciate their sourcing practices, too. Maybe I'll come back to try some of their other offerings.
author: Dang J.

description: The salmon taco and wild mushroom taco were a delight - on top of a layer of guac with fresh ingredients! Lots of different salsas - loved the refried black beans. We did not go away hungary!!
author: Coco J.

description:
So I was walking down 24th st, and I just finished a JV football scrimmage against Galileo high school. Walk towards home, I came in and I thought it would be nice to have a burrito for lunch- I've actually been craving this place ever since I was craving a burrito.

I came in, the cashier was a pretty chill guy, not a McDonalds type person but one that you can engage in a small conversation with, and that's nice to have, especially if you can't make your decision then this guy can convince you to get good food.

So I got myself a Super Burrito with Carnitas and some mexican rice. It was not bad at all! The meat in the burrito was nice and chunky, which I like... and it was tender- making sure that "Chunky" doesn't mean something bad. The mexican rice was pretty decent, but it was just mexican rice and I honestly can't decide on what good rice is good. I mean, bad rice is bad, and good rice is good... c'mon now!

Overall, I would come back to this place anytime! Burritos weren't so bad and were pretty filled and chunky (in a good way). It was also a decent size for somebody who was hungry... or for a high school JV football player who just finished a scrimmage. Gotta like this place... and just like the miracle whip commercial, "It's not for everybody!"
author: Bryan S.

description: FOOD POISON hell is the result of my chorizo experience from this restaurant. I've been to the Little Chihuahua on Divisadero, I eat regularly at the dirty El Farolito next to BART on Mission, one of my favorite taco locales is the truck by Best Buy... Why is it that when I go to upscale Little Chihuahua in upscale Noe Valley I'm poisoned by E. COLI, SALMONELLA or what ever horrible unsanitary unhygienic parasite that's colonizing their food? To top it all off they even have a little sign at the counter touting their top shelf chorizo. What a joke! Never again you impostors! You're lucky if I don't report you to the health department and your chorizo supplier to the FDA!
author: Derrxck L.

description:
I love this place.  The tostada salad with shrimp got me hooked.  It's so fresh with delish chunks of mango and avocado...mmm.  Also, the tortilla soup rocks (get one and share) and so does the plantain and black bean burrito, a must try.

And if you have room for dessert, get the sopapilla for dessert if it's available, with Mexican chocolate ice cream, which is such a nice complement to the cinnamon-y goodness of the sopapilla.  One is plenty to share between 2-3 people.
author: Tai N.

description: Excellent chicken enchiladas and their nachos are also great!! Lovely service everytime I come here
author: Linda M.

description:
I pretty much love this place.  This might be because I love a good salsa bar and, my goodness, Little Chihuahua has a good salsa bar.  All their food is good, but I find that the standouts are the burritos, salads, and enchiladas.  The service here is great-- the staff is very friendly and food is prepared quickly.

The prices are fair, and their beer prices ($3 pints last time I was there) are excellent.  Although the prices may be higher than some other taquerias, the quality of their food is superior.  All entrees come with chips and salsa, and my boyfriend and I frequently split a plate of enchiladas, and order a side of guacamole to devour with the chips and salsa.  It's a great dinner that we pair with pints or a pitcher of sangria and it still doesn't break the bank.  

Bottom line: good food, good prices, good service.
author: Steve B.

description:
Why oh why, Little Chihuahua?! You had the best burritos in town - bar none! Then the catastrophe that was tonight... 

I love(d) your burritos... just the right amount of spice, tender juicy steak bits, always perfect. Somehow though, tonight, you didn't just miss the mark, you were the epic fail that walks into a plate glass window - the one that 'appears out of no-where'. 

I always order the same thing when I go in, well - super or super baby - but the filling is always the same... and never once have I ever asked for jalapenos -- and I didn't do it tonight either, yet somehow there they were. Not just a few either, a whole bunch of them packed into the top half of my burrito... and I gotta say - my dining experience was ruined. I get horrible heart burn if I eat pickled jalapenos (which is why I don't order them), but I always order them on the other burrito in my order - which is a different meat altogether, so really this is kind of inexcusable - and where was my extra cilantro?! 

Oh, Little Chihuahua, you've let me down. Tonight was below your par. Especially since the refried black beens were sweet... weird, and definitely not a fan. 

I want to go back - but I'm just not sure I can trust you... jalapenos where they shouldn't be, missing cilantro, sweet black beans, dry burritos... Backslides like these usually mean trouble in the kitchen (I've been in kitchens before, and I speak from experience) -- prove me wrong Little Chihuahua! I liked you, but you betrayed me...
author: Elizabeth D.

description:
I've got a fond attachment to plantains ever since I found out about them. Which is why the idea of putting them in a burrito naturally intrigued me. So I bookmarked The Little Chihuahua (the one by Haight) and just hoped that maybe one of the many visits to Haight would end (or start) with a burrito. 

Luckily today was that day, only we were walking down a street in Noe Valley today and seen that there's one here too! So in we went. The staff was nice and our food came quick. 

Fried Plantain and Black Bean Burrito: I have to admit that this was one of the best burritos I've had. The plantain was fried perfectly and all the flavors were noticeable. I really just don't know how to explain how awesome this burrito was only that the flavors were enhanced by some of their Chipotle Salsa from their salsa bar which was also pretty great! 

As a (mostly) vegetarian this place has a great selection of stuff to put in your food like tofu, grilled veggies and mushrooms. It's always a relief when I have more veggie options at a burrito place than just rice, beans and cheese. 

I can't wait to come back for more!
author: James M.

description:
Love the Divis spot, but love this place even more. The food makes my mouth water - love the great quality meats, the freshness of the chips and salsa, and how nothing feels loaded with grease. I don't think I've gotten anything here that I don't like from the well-balanced tostadas, to the savory garlic shrimp burrito, to something I just tried today for the first time and HIGHLY recommend... the Sopapilla with tequila ice cream. It's like sweet heaven on a plate, then on your tongue, then in your belly. Mmm.

This location gives you more breathing room than the Divis location and has a nice back patio. Stop by here, you won't regret it.
author: Bryant T.

description: Open July 4th.
author: Thomas C.

description: The food was good. I had a tostada salad with chicken. It was great. It was made with a mango salsa and had large chunks of cucumber in it. All the ingredients tasted really fresh. My husband ordered a burrito with carne asada. It was okay, nothing special. They have a salsa bar with some really great salsa options. The roasted tomato salsa was really tasty. The staff was okay, not particularly friendly. The place could have been cleaner. I would go back again.
author: Traci B.

description: Ok Noe.  I don't like you and you don't like me.  I get it.  So why on earth would you taunt me by putting a very nice little mex place way up the hill far away from my apartment?  It's a fair walk up the hill to get a baby steak burrito (which is delicious and a proper smaller portion fit for normal human consumption) but it sure beats walking down the hill to Papalote.
author: David S.

description:
I came here after doing a search veg tacos and I must say, their mushroom tacos and tofu tacos are delicious. 

Though when I went there for the first time, the girl at the counter wanted nothing to do with me, so she rang me up before I could get one of those real-sugar cokes. However, let's just chalk that up to having to working on Saturday and I will be coming back for my taco fixes.
author: Leslie T.

description:
Oy vey.  This was simply horrible.  Seriously...and I was even starving!  This restaurant came highly recommended to my friend so we thought we'd give it a go.  Girlfriend please.  We might have known better.  Noe Valley.  Nice young hipsters took our orders--smurf hats, baby Gap jeans and all.  

We ordered carnitas nachos, 1 chicken chile verde taco and 1 carne asada taco.  And a carafe of sangria.  

The salsa bar is always something that makes me happy...except when the salsa all tastes like different shades of bland.  The scary green-black was by far the best, but still not wonderful.  The tacos arrived cold.  The nachos were alright I guess, but not worth the $10 some-odd bucks we paid for them. The carnitas were very bland and underwhelming.  And geez, at least lube us up with good booze!  That's how the Velvet Cantina is still around, I think.  The sangria was essentially really expensive punch gone slightly off.

Kids, save your hard-earned cash and get yer butts to a real Mexican restaurant.  We live in San Francisco so there's no excuse for this nonsense.  You shouldn't leave dinner angry.
author: Katherine P.

description:
We went here for brunch and after eating some awesome chili quilies (with added delicious wild mushrooms) I couldn't figure out why this place wasn't packed!  Come on Noe Valley- no wait for brunch on a saturday- you should be all over this!!!
First of all , there is a salsa bar that has 5 delicious salsa and we tried them all.  The chips were nice and hot and almost melt in your mouth!  
I loved my food and hubby's food as well (plantain and black bean burrito).  Veggie options also avaliable! 
Food was hot, nummy and awesome- I can't wait to go back!
And to the chick who complained about bussing her own table- really?!?!?
author: Dangerous T.

description:
Little Chihuahua really hits the Noe Valley sweet spot: great food, casual vibe, good for kids and beer and wine for the parents.

The setup here is upscale fast food: order at the counter when you walk in, get a number, and in a hurry your food is delivered to your table.  While you wait, pick up some water, utensils and one or three salsas from the salsa bar.

I've explored the menu a bit and my current go-to order is the chicken super baby - it's got all the good extras of the super, but in a slightly smaller, but still totally filling, size.

Would love to see more places like this in the Valley for a solid weeknight dinner.
author: Eric S.

description:
For what this is, I guess it is OK.  And what this is is some strange experiment trying to make healthy mexican food.  Something no one wants.

   The carnitas was ok , but definitely lacking in the flavor and texture area.  If  I wanted unsalted roast pork, I would have ordered that, but I wanted carnitas, which is salty, flavorful and is fried in its own rendered fat to yield a crispy yummy bark on the outside of the meat.  None of that here at the Perro De Salud or whatever this place is called.

   Served on a whole wheat tortilla.  Never a good idea.  

    Lastly, I had the tortilla soup, which every resturaunt seems to do one of two ways... the yummy broth based way, or the not so yummy sort of pureed way.  This was the puree sort of soup, so if you like that then you might like the soup here.

  The salsas seemed to me to be very strangely flavored  The habanero salsa was sweet, for instance.. and not really all that hot.

   So, in closing, if you want good Mexican food, this does not seem to be the place.  If you are into "wraps" and "lo-cal", this might be the Pinche Perro de Salud for you.
author: Bad Y.

description: Plantain burrito is perfect, and the best is that you don't need to be vegetarian to appreciate it!! :)
author: Gregoire V.

description:
I kind of love coming here for brunch. The food is really good, the service is quick, and the back patio is usually empty.  

Me likes.
author: Mister G.

description: The chorizo was beyond belief amazing!!! The carne asada was a little gristly. It was really busy, but it was Friday night, so that is expected. Though I would recommend that the management staff more counter people for a quicker turn around. The staff was efficient and friendly. Good experience.
author: Claire A.

description:
Little Chihuahua is leagues better than standard Mexican fare and offers awesome vegetarian options for those of us that don't eat carnitas with every meal.

To some of the other reviews:
Some of us are very grateful for healthy options. There are times i want greasy, cheesy, alcohol-soaking-up, but not always. And actually, the options here may be healthier, but it's still not a nutritionist's delight.

Also, Casa Mexicana is run of them mill, iceberg lettuce kind of Mexican. After Little Chihuahua I never plan to eat at Casa ever again (and haven't since Little Chihuahua has opened).

Fact is that Little Chihuahua offers great food in a nice place and I haven't been to any other place recently that can compare.
author: Ennis O.

description: Fantastic "upscale taqueria". The tacos were excellent and the salsa was even better. The music was awesome and so is the decor.
author: Will D.

description: For the quality and size of food, the prices were a bit steep. Also, there aren't any corn tortilla options so keep that in mind if you don't enjoy wheat/flour tortillas.
author: Lily C.

description:
$2 Anchor Steam pint on tap, cold, perfectly pulled.
Nachos that came just as ordered: 
black beans were really black (not refried or pintos or, 'gosh, sorry [sullen shrug], I thought you wanted ground meat') ; sour cream was replaced by extra guacamole (and plenty of it); cook went 'easy on the cheese' as desired.
ALL was DELICIOUS -- especially when covered with six varieties of tasty, fresh salsas.  

We sat outside on the back patio on a HOT day in SF. 
 
All who work here were as friendly as they were efficient.  I second Bryan's comments from last month about the simple but far from universal joys in finding a cashier who knows what's up, has a chill 'tude, and remembers that he can share his opinions in ways that make everyone feel good.

We'll be back.  
Often.
author: Scott C.

description:
Having just finished a tour de force of Ibiza with an epic Sander Van Doorn set at Amnesia, I had just one thing on my mind as I started the 6,000 mile journey home. Well, two things. I needed sleep (got some on the flight). And I needed, craved, desired, must have, a burrito.

Stepping into Little Chihuahua, it felt like the end of a journey. The words came in a rush out of my mouth: grilled chicken, black beans, salsa, wheat tortilla. I had dreamed of you. Wishes for you. Earned you.

The burrito delivered nothing but deep, delicious satisfaction. Even better, Humphry Slocombe has started doing custom flavors, and I celebrated with tequila vanilla. Oh yes. No bad memories of spring break here. Just some rich vanilla with a hint of the juice. An only in San Francisco original that left me thinking, it was good, really good, to be home.
author: Jason B.

description: Was not expecting much from this place. Was just looking for a place that was near my pad.  they close at 10, and got  there at 930, so naturally I got it togo. people in the industry would appreiciate this gesture, and they did.  I got the carnitas burrito and was a bit disappointed on the size for the price.  however, it made up for its flavor. real tasty. I give it a 4 for the actual quality.  I do prefer a giant burritos, which I feel they should consider:) but still top notch.
author: EJ B.

description:
I'm eating here once/week now.

The carne asada is simply the best around.  I love the Super Baby burrito - a great value as it's plenty of food for me - especially supplemented with chips and salsa.

Nachos are unbelievable.  

The staff are great and have even befriended my toddler daughter.  BTW - it's great for kids.  If you go early you will find out for yourself as half the kids in Noe Valley must consider LC a staple.  But my toddler daughter eats loves the kids burrito.
author: Bill V.

description:
We used to absolutely love this place. The staff always knew our order and were really personable, particularly Thomas & Fontaine. They made the experience better. Now the staff is always changing and it less desirable to go regularly. We wish there was less turnover in the staff! 

The food is usually fairly consistent. Since the shift in staff, we've ordered vegan burritos that ended up with cheese in it. We do appreciate the quality of ingredients. It is still our go to burrito place.
author: Robin H.

description:
Nice clean space. Great service. Awesome ingredients and a nice salsa bar. Generous portions. Definitely your best option for clean, healthy california style mexican food for Noe and Castro valleys.

If you want the more traditional gut bomb yet always delicious real mexican food drop down to the mission.
author: James H.

description: We ordered take out from here the other day. It was sooooo good. We ordered the quesadillas & chicken enchiladas to share. The sides of guacamole, beans & rice were tasty too. The portions lasted 2 days they were that big. The cost was average too and it's only round the corner so I'll definitely be back!
author: Kelly M.

description:
This place is so amazing.   Everything is fresh and delicious and their specialty burritos (like the garlic shrimp) are soooo good.

My only complaint is that their chips are HORRIBLE.  I'm not sure what they do to them, but they're super oily and the oil has a really bad after taste.  I usually eat 2 or 3 and then I can't stand it anymore.  Please fix the chips Little Chihuahua friends :)
author: Jeff C.

description: Tried this place once for dinner wasn't good, strange flavors in multiple dishes and otherwise tired gringo Mexican food. Giving it the benefit of the doubt we went back for brunch. The potatoes had the same outputting flavor, the eggs tasted like they were bought in bulk packaged and prescrambled, and were overlooked to boot. At least the staff was friendly this time. Plus a restaurant this pricey making you bus your own tables? I think not.
author: Jared Z.

description:
We love this place and are so glad it's in Noe Valley.

I always have the tostada salad without the shell and corn tortillas on the side. I have them put 1/2 carne asada, and 1/2 carnitas. Extra dressing and BAM! Beauty.

Prices are a little high I think, so that's why only 4 stars.
author: Min M.

description:
Terrific addition to Noe's restaurant scene - easy, fresh and good food, cheap! Love it! We eat there, or do takeout, at least 1x/week. Perfect for the toddler too, they actually have enough high chairs for all the mini patrons to use. 

It was always hard for me to believe that Noe was less than 1 mile away from the Mission yet we had ZERO mexican food - thank you Little Chihuahua, you are a huge PLUS to 24th Street. I love the basics here... chicken burrito - i've also had the super chicken burrito but you know what? You don't need the super version with the sour cream, cheese, etc...  b/c the regular version is so fresh and tasty, it is great by itself! The salsa here is fresh and delish! yay!
author: Heather F.

description:
I liked that they did not overcharge for beers.... which were terrific. 

A few things:
This not Mexican food, and neither is Taco Bell.  Though Taco Bell might be more authentic.

The food is bland and the chips are over-salted.  This is the work of  amateurs.... whose food is better in a photo than actually eaten.   I find it sad that they pass off blended-canned-tomato slop for sauce.   Someone has some really bad taste and lacks basic cooking skills.

Its overpriced.  $10.xx for carne asada enchiladas is obnoxious when I consider that Trader Joes frozen enchiladas are actually better.  Seriously -- better.

Bus your own table?  Not only is it strange to pay north of $10.00 for bad food ... I gotta bus my own table? wha?  Worse -- they actually make it difficult.  The "busing station" is a study in how *not* to design a busing station.  

The beers are good, the people working there seem nice -- however, the food sucks.
author: mario w.

description:
BEST TOSTADA SALAD EVER. Enough said.

I come here for their delectable salad when I get veggie cravings. Choice of grilled veggies or tofu or meat... With black beans, avocado, mango, queso fresco cubes... All on top of fresh mixed greens in a freshly made tortilla bowl. Not to mention they have a tasty salsa bar and complementary tortilla chips!

Oh boy...I just made myself crave this salad again... Lunch time!

You won't be disappointed!!
author: Marie W.

description:
There are certain restaurants where you want to keep it as a secret to avoid long lines and annoying patrons.   And this is one of them.   My bf started eating here because of their Fried Plantains Burritos.   He introduced me to it and wow.  It's has that perfect mix of sweet and savory.   

I finally ventured outside of the Fried Plantains Burritos and tried the Carnitas Tostada.  It comes with a nice vinaigrette dressing that compliments the black beans, mixed greens and mango salsa.  It's one of their biggest portion dishes so I ended up saving half of it for lunch the next day.   Their salsa variety is pretty awesome.  I like their roasted pepper salsa the best.   Sweet and spicy at the same time. 

The staff is flexible and uber friendly.   They never give you a dirty look if you ask for seconds on the chips or a cup with ice.   

I like that they break down their trash into compostable, recycling and trash.   I also believe their ingredients are fresh and organic.   Oh and I love the music they play there.   Who doesn't love the Killers or Franz Ferdinand.  

This has become our favorite Mexican restaurant.
author: Morgan L.

description: Best Mexican food in Noe by far ... burritos always a favorite ... awesome guac ... great salsa bar ... good beer and wine selection as well ... a great addition to the neighborhood.
author: Jeffrey W.

description:
Rating: 3 1/2 stars.  Definitely potential for a 4-star rating on a future trip.

Came here for dinner Friday night with high hopes.  I love Mexican food and was hoping that Little Chihuahua could become a nice alternative to prevent me from eating too much Papalote in one week.

It wasn't bad!  We shared the black bean and plantain burrito, on recommendation from many Yelpers, and the regular nachos.  Both were pretty good.  The burrito was quite creative and unlike any burrito I've tried before.  I love plantains and the burrito created a nice contrast between the sweetness of the plantains and the other spicier Mexican flavors.  I would totally get it again!

Service was great and the portion sizes were good as well.  I shared the burrito with my male companion and we were both stuffed afterwards.  We barely touched our nachos because the 1/2 burrito was so filling.  

Why 3.5 stars, you ask?  There are NO good salsas!  This wouldn't really be an issue if I thought the burrito could stand on its own. While I thought the burrito was quite good, I definitely think it could have used a good salsa.  There were 5 salsas in the salsa bar (I was SO hopeful when I saw a salsa bar!), but alas, not one of the salsas was good.  We kept trying to mix them, but never found a combo or flavor that we liked.  Also, this place is a bit pricey.

That said, I like that they have different sizes for their burritos (the "Baby Burrito") if you don't really feel like having a food baby afterwards.  I'm not sure how big the Baby Burrito is, but I will definitely check that out when I'm not sharing.

This place has potential and I would try it again to try different items on the menu.  Do something about the salsa, though!  Add some flavor!
author: Julie S.

description:
Little Chihuaha catered this party at a friend of a friends.

The spread was a fajita bar of chicken, pork and steak with all the various fillings and toppings.  The food was solid and definitely seemed a cut above the usual Taqueria fare.  I asked the hosts if it was expensive and they said it wasn't that bad (especially compared to a lot of catering companies in SF).  

The food was good enough, I dropped by the Noe Valley location.  The food is a little expensive, but the place is nicer and feels a little more upscale than the usual Taqueria with tacky decorations and yellow and purple walls.  I'd definitely pick this place over the usual random Taqueria (however, if I'm looking for great Mexican food, I'd go to the Mission)
author: Peter S.

description:
This review is only on a take-out burrito that was ordered today. Chips that came with it were really addicting, salsa was good. Burrito itself was unique with cabbage, but I just thought the burrito itself was too dry. Maybe this one lacked more pica de gallo? Or maybe I should've ordered the "super" burrito? I dunno, but I had to use my own hot sauce, and a lot of it...

not bad though for a quick mexican fix...but if i had more time, i'd rather go down to mission and get something there.
author: Carol L.

description:
Noe Valley is a great spot to live, except that there is virtually no casual dining.  You can drink coffee all day long, then go spend $80 for a fancy-pants dinner.  But recently, I was pleased to discover that Little Chihuahua had broken into Noe Valley, the Land of the Bourgeois Brunch.  I'd had a fun experience at their other Divisadero location, so I was amped that now I had one closer to home.

It's a good spot for a quick burrito or casual pre-party dinner. The prices are a little steep - average $9-12 for a burrito, but they've got carafes of sangria or margarita for $15-18, which isn't too bad. I was bummed by the limited menu - nothing fancy like chile rellenos - but they can wrap up some high-quality meats (Niman Ranch or Rosie's Chicken).  I hear their black bean and plantain burrito won Best of the Bay for veggie burrito.  Add to that a decent salsa bar and you're looking pretty appealing here in the Noe.
author: Mari C.

description: Great lunch spot - very affordable and delicious. Enjoyed the free chips and salsas. Gauc was a good value. Will be back.
author: Sean S.

description:
I wouldn't say this place serves traditional mexican food but nevertheless, it is delicious (and much healthier).  

I had the black bean and plantain burrito which was great.  They have a salsa bar.  That is what I am talking about!  I don't like waiting for the waiter to realize I have run out of salsa.

Also be sure to try the watermelon juice=amazing (almost tastes strawberry-ish)


service 3/5
food 4/5
drinks 5/5
author: Claire M.

description:
I would give Little Chihuahua 4 stars if I did not have to bus my own table. I like the food. I like the staff. But for the price? Please just bus my table for me. The place is nice enough that I actually feel awkward doing it. What adds to the awkwardness is that I can barely reach the bussing station, literally. I'm 5'2" and can barely reach, let alone see into the bins. Very likely that I will one day drop something in and break it, and I will not be sorry. 

I see this thought echoed elsewhere on their Yelp page. Maybe they should acquiesce on this one thing to make their customers happier :)
author: Jennifer C.

description: I'm not sure I get the appeal of Little Chihuahua.  Yes, their roasted tomato salsa is tasty and yes, they have all the usual combinations of a quality taqueria.  However, all their prices are jacked up compared with their competitors in the Mission.  3 stars perfectly describes my feelings...A-OK.
author: Jeremy G.

description: Though the Plantain Burrito is the go-to burrito at any Little Chihuahua (and worth trying if you haven't yet), I'm surprised that no Yelp reviews mention the Grilled Vegetables. Well seasoned, squashy, and less guilt inducing then the sodium rich chorizo, the veggie burrito is my "once or twice a week, can't decide what to eat" go to. Chips are always warm, staff is always nice.
author: David M.

description:
I heard good things, so I tried it. The only reason why I give it 4 stars is because it's a little expensive for the taqueria experience, but there are reasons for that.

I had the steak burrito - excellent! The steak was marinated with lime and herbs - much different than what I'm used to trying in carne asada burritos. It wasn't big, but it had the right flavors going on. It was more or less the perfect steak burrito. It came with chips and access to the salsa bar, which was nothing less than spectacular!

I would go there just for a meal of their wonderful salsas and chips if they would let me. The habanero salsa was the perfect blend of spice and fruit flavors. Yes, it was hot. But the flavor was so good, I set myself up with plenty of cool liquids just so I could dive in, break, dive in, break, dive in...I really tortured myself because it was that good! The tomatillo salsa was just as good with the perfect blend of spiciness and sweetness.

I will go back, eventually. Go for the excellent food. It's worth the higher price.
author: John F.

description: My friend gets us take out here every time I am in town.  She grabs takeout here once a week, and I think I probably could too.  It's always good to have some delicious Mexican food (none to be found in Mpls).  This time I did the veggie salad.  I don't know how a salad can be so darn good, but it was!  Yum.   The only bummer is the chips with the guacamole, they seem like they could be so much better.
author: D B.

description:
I'm a big fan of Papalote but after stumbling upon this place in my hood I say they definitely rival my old favorite. I had the plantain and black bean burrito and I have to say it is now my favorite burrito. Their salsa selections were lovely, ranging from sweet, to fire-roasted and smoldering. 

I plan to go back and try every little vegetarian thing they have on their menu (which looked like a lot!)
author: max k.

description: Love the carne asada!  Not so crazy about bussing my own table or the sometimes loud music.  Very friendly folks, good neighborhood option.
author: Karen B.

description:
The 2nd incarnation of The Little Chihuahua is now open on 24th street.

They're in the space that was formerly Miss Millie's and one other brunch place, right next to Lupa.

First impressions: They did a nice light remodel on the space - wood benches and a decent amount of seating.  There are also some stools in the window if you'd like to have a view of the sidewalk while you eat.

They've got a good salsa bar.  (and some decently spicy habanero salsa in it - always a plus for me.)

The burritos are Mission style: rice, beans, salsa and meat.  They also have a super if you're a fan of sour cream & guacamole.  

I had carnitas - one of my acid tests for a place.  While good, they lacked that crunchiness that comes from grilling or frying after braising.
author: Stephan W.

description:
Not a bad little place. I think I'll eat there instead of take out next time.

I do want to try their Plantain Burrito, I heard it was really good. Stay tuned for a Review Update
author: Eric A.

description: THEIR TORTILLA SOUP. why have I waited this long to try this establishment?
author: S B.

description: I love plantains and black beans, so to walk by a place that wrapped all that goodness into a burrito...i had to go in.  It was all that I hoped and more, so will be back again.  :)
author: beverly l.

description:
We went to this place because of the good Yelp ratings and its close location.
Their brunch menu seemed exciting and the food looked fun. The taste was not great though.
 Not bad, just uneventful. It lacked some kick. I thought I may have been in some sort of strange mood because the food presentation did not match the taste, but my party agreed with me.
The Little Chihuahua is just another Mexican inspired informal spot to eat on the (somewhat) cheap. There is nothing special.
author: Jose S.

description: The guacamole enchiladas are amazing! I'm a picky enchilada eater and these were some of the best. They give you an option of red or green sauce...get both!
author: Shannonagins B.

description:
I guess the name of the place is sorta a nod to Taco Bell, makes sense. Basically what you have here is a chain in waiting, Mexican food for white people. Gather it may be "healthy" but the food is quite bland. If you're looking for Mexican retirement home cafeteria food you've found it. Plus, the cool thing is on almost any given night you'll run into ill behaved kids and their parents who don't really care how they behave as long as they don't have to deal with them for an hour or so. 
I can't recommend this place for anyone who has ever had and enjoyed real Mexican food. If you're a fan of say The Cheese Cake Factory or Applebee's, this place could be right up your alley. If you like authentic Mexican food, walk or drive 4-5 blocks and there are plenty of options.
There is a very cool out door space, chips + salsa + beer out there can be nice...but buy a few tacos or burritos down the street if you need a meal.

2 stars only for the patio + nice staff.
author: Robert P.

description: Really happy to have this place in Noe, and I prefer the Noe location to the Divisadero location (food is good at both, but the 24th St. location is a little less cramped). Black bean and plantain burrito is heavenly, but I've been forcing myself to branch out lately. Haven't been disappointed yet, and the tofu enchiladas might have actually pushed the bean/plantain burrito out of its top spot. My only (very minor) complaint...they used to have great iced tea but they recently changed it out. Not as happy with the new version.
author: Pat M.

description: I'm  bumping LC  back up to 4 stars  because I ate there a few times in the last month and the service is a lot better.
author: Christopher T.

description:
Now, THIS is what I love about Cali-Mexican food! 

The tacos are delicious!! Nice mix of onion and cilantro. The grilled veggie burrito was perfectly seasoned - no need to add salt. The restaurant has a nice ambiance, too. There's a good amount of seating. We will definitely go back.
author: Heidi L.

description:
Delicious. This place was recommended by a friend and so we trekked from Oakland (which is actually easy from BART to muni N get off at Judah and it's a few blocks). And you know what? It was worth it. 

Came around 8 on a Saturday night and it was busy the whole time we were there. Also noticed they do take out. I got a salmon burrito and my boyfriend got shrimp (he had gotten chicken last time and said it was a little on the spicy side and he loves spice so beware). I was skeptical of salmon, but it was one of the best burritos I've ever had (and they use fresh seafood). They give you chips and their is a salsa bar. My margarita was delicious (made with a bit of oj for a twist), a full beer glass size for $5. My bf got a Negra Modelo on tap for $3. 

The staff was really friendly. You order at the counter and choose a table and they bring your food. The place is on the small side, but cute and decorated nicely. I would go back for the salmon burrito and try the tofu-yum.
author: J E.

description:
got the carne asada taco and carnitas taco. i couldnt decide which one i liked more...the carnitas taco meat was cooked so amazingly - it was so soft and tender that it just melted in your mouth. all of the meat was very well seasoned and had tons of flavor. if you're a garlic fan, go for the shrimp burrito.

can't wait to come back and try more, including the mexican root beer float (tequila ice cream?!)
author: Stephanie C.

description:
I was looking forward to trying this place.

This is a yuppified version of a taqueria. The horchata was delicious, thick, creamy with ample amounts of cinnamon and bumped up this review. The chips and salsa were standard. I appreciated the five or so available selections of salsa. However, the salsa bar reminded me a bit of El Pollo Loco. This is not a bad thing. I love El Pollo Loco

Unfortunately,  the entrees were utterly disappointing. I ordered one carne asada taco and one carnitas taco. The meat in both tacos were cold. This was only reinforced by the piping hot side of rice I ordered. Both tacos had plenty of meat, but the meat in both were bland and "soggy" from all of the other fixings served with the tacos. 

My dining companion ordered tofu enchiladas, which arrived lukewarm.  

NOTE: This last part is not the restaurant's fault and not factored into this review. We went to to dinner at 6:30 pm on a weekend, and we hit the prime dining hour for families. Several groups of parents allowed their children to run amok, screaming and throwing food. (I blame the parents) The place is small, and the noise carried throughout making conversation impossible.  We were not the only ones who noticed. We would have sat at the front counter away from them, but there were three strollers parked in front of the counter, thus making them inaccessible.
author: Greg C.

description:
Now that's what I call Noe Valley priced Mexican! 

$26 bucks for a burrito and a salad and two drinks. Ay caramba.

Frankly not worth it. My Pollo Tostada was just a shell with a lot of green salad filler and perhaps (if I'm being generous) a quarter of a chicken fillet on top. Very very average. Stick to Mariachi's in the Mission I say.
author: zoe b.

description: Me and chili verde got a thing going on, and so I was really seduced by the fact that they have chili verde tofu as a "meat" option. That, combined with the vegetarian refried black beans made for quite the burrito. And it was good, but not steal-my-heart-away-good. Try it out, though.
author: David S.

description: The Little Chihuahua is a good option for a quick and inexpensive meal.  They have a bunch of locations around town, all serving tasty Mexican fare.  I'm a fan of the chicken tortilla soup.
author: Dan W.

description: Yum. good, fresh ingredients, good salsa bar, quickish service, cheap beers if you eat in.
author: martin l.

description: I love The Little Chihuahua! It's a bit pricier than most Mexican restaurants in the area, but what's a few extra bucks when you're getting a much higher-quality product? I always get the beans-rice-and-cheese burrito, but I really like that they use meats from sources that use sustainable farming. This means that you're not eating meat from factory farms. And that's totally awesome.
author: Jessica L.

description: I really want to like this place. Their menu sounds good, their ingridients taste like they are high-quality and fresh, the salsa at the salsa bar is yummy, the staff is nice. But the food is just oh so bland. I expect Mexican food to pop, but here everything is really underseasoned. Every time I eat here, I end up feeling really unsatisfied and thinking "what a waste of calories". Next time I want a burrito, I'll drive the extra mile to the Mission.
author: Ann P.

description:
We love this little taco place!

It's quick and easy. The chorizo tacos are to die for! We also love the nachos and the tostada salad. And they have a salsa bar with habanero salsa that is actually SPICY! Whoo hoo!

Great neighborhood spot!
author: Alex M.

description: Love this place. I will say - there are so many good options in San Francisco in terms of Mexican food. This one is not to be overlooked. I tend to come here for the standard super burrito, and I highly recommend the chile verde chicken (hold the cabbage). I'm also a big fan of their chipotle salsa which, unlike Papalote with their salsa, they're not stingy about letting you have as much as you need. Glad to have these guys in my neighborhood.
author: Eli Z.

description: Super Burrito with Carne Asada + refried pinto beans...extra hot sauce.  What more can i ask for.  Super delicious burrito and I LOVE that they have an awesome self-help salsa bar.  Their habanero salsa is super spicy, perfect for someone who enjoys spicy salsa, but they also have regular salsa and other non-spicy options.  Overall very solid Mexican place.  This joint would still fare well in the Mission - it's that good!
author: Heather Y.

description: I had sweet platains in my burrito, it was awesome! And the chipotle sauce is also really good!
author: Allison R.

description: Great Mexican food, nice booths in the back, ample selection of Mexican boozes. But.... sloppy salsa booth, sometime, they run out of salsa I want and sometimes, the salsas are "water-down" which is disgusting.  Need to work on their salsa booth so get an extra star.  Plus side, it's on a nice street in a nice spot.
author: Pepe W.

description:
Honestly, good but not great.  I am all for sustainable, organic food and I am willing to pay for better ingredients.  The prices were definitely reflective of more organic and less lard, but sometimes lard has its place.  The restaurant is nice and open, plenty of tables in back and a really yummy salsa bar.  The roasted tomato salsa was exceptionally good.  It had the perfect smoked flavor to it.  My hubby and I ordered between us, a plantain/black bean burrito, the pork stew and a side of guacamole.  The guacamole needed some serious doctoring.  It was pretty bland.  I added some salt, pepper and the roasted salsa and that made my taste buds much happier..  My plantain burrito was really good.  Not too heavy and a nice flavor blend.  9 dollars worth?  Nope. I think it is about 2 bucks too much.

Hubby, who loves his food spicy was sweating it out over the stew.  The peppers they used must have been simmering for a long time to exude such a fire.

Over all a good fix for a quick meal in the hood.  Especially when I don't want to deal with the Mission.
author: Monika S.

description: I love this restaurant.  The staff is very professional and pleasant.  Food tastes amazing.  I recommend it to any and everyone :)
author: Joseph G.

description: I have only been to this place a couple of times and really love the food there. Don't know what "authentic" is supposed to be but the meat and other ingredients are delicious. Love their roasted tomato salsa. Seems like a hip place.
author: R L.

description: I go here at least once a month. It is my go-to burrito place in The City. Plantain burrito all the way! Love you Little Chihuahua!
author: Amanda W.

description: I think I might like you more, Mr Chihuahua if your salsa wasn't so bad. Seriously, they're all bad.
author: Ian W.

description: I've been to this place for both eat in and take out- mostly burritos- always good, generous portions and fresh. Friendly staff and low key seating- no problems to report with this place.
author: christine l.

description:
This weekend I was in the mood for a breakfast burrito. I live in the Mission so I stopped by Papalote. Their basic Denver (mush, onions, peppers and cheese) was almost $10 + $4.50 for Soyriso...not!  I had errands in Noe so I went to Little Chihuahua. Their breakfast burrito is $6.50 and includes roasted potatoes and poblano peppers. To add meat was $2.50. It was huge and delicious. People were super nice...ingred's are sustainably sourced. And a great salsa bar.

Hello new favorite! Hopefully you wont let fame go to your head or your prices like Paplote.
author: Steven M.

description: Good, fresh, tasty and fairly priced Mexican food! I wish their salsa was a bit better... but they have beer on tap and good wines by the glass. I order out at least once a week there. Also the staff is very professional and friendly.
author: Chris W.

description: Plantains with steak or chicken burrito fabulous! A but pricey, but yummy! Nice customer service and kid friendly.
author: Sabiha D.

description: I live across the street and eat here at least a couple times a month. Seems like the quality has gone down and last night the salsa tasted like bleach and I feel Ill this morning.
author: G. John E.

description:
I frequent this place a lot because I live nearby. I gotta give them 5 stars because the food is consistently fresh and delicious and the staff is always super nice and friendly. I am obsessed with the big salad. Holy mound of fresh, yummy veggies. And the salsa bar is amazing! My only very small complaint would be that the chips sometimes taste like the oil they were cooked in was burnt but theyre usually salty, hot and delicious! Is that's my only complaint, they def get
5 stars!
author: amy W.

description:
This is healthy mexican *INSPIRED* food.  That's direct from their website so if you're looking for authentic why aren't you looking in the Mission area?

That aside, this place is clean, quick, not too bad on the budget.  Brunch, Lunch and Dinner - enjoyed it all.  Lots of choices for various diet needs.

Seating is tight - what place in San Fran isn't right?

Brunch is DELISH!!  The amount of food on one plate is enough for both the hubs and I to have a satisfying meal as well as our fill of chips and salsa and Watermelon Fresca.  So next time you don't want to wait an hour for a Toast table walk further up the hill on 24th and get a seat here. 

They've just recently added heating lamps for a small outdoor seating area in the back.

Everything is made to order and you can watch the kitchen as they make it.

After your full meal take a stroll along 24th street Noe Valley for shopping and a sweet treat.
author: Marti P.

description:
Nom, nom, nom, nom....

Delicious!  As I was eating, I actually thought to myself how I wish I lived closer to this place so I could easily stop her after a night of drinking for a burrito.

I had a pretty standard super burrito, with whole wheat tortilla, veggie black beans, pollo asado, and no rice.  The tortilla was all toasty and the filling was delicious with a slightly tangy taste.  I liked the pico de gallo and roasted tomatillo(sp?) salsas too, but the others didn't do much for me.

Staff was really friendly.  After I grabbed my beer from the fridge, one of the guys could tell I was looking around for a lime and offered me some.  I'll definitely be back!
author: Matthew P.

description: Tasty, relatively in-expensive and has a nice little outdoor patio.
author: Mark C.

description: Some items on the menu are worth what you pay, but you have to watch out who takes the order from you. I went for a pick up and ordered my usual taco that has a bit of a change from what is actually on the menu. But the guy at the cash register had to go in length to explain that it would cost way more and not even listening that I say I don't care, I'll pay for it, and still he goes on and on...... Also, they need to hire more people, so the one who takes the money from you would not squeeze lime into beer bottle using the very same fingers, so nasty!!!!!!!!!!, Fortunately, I did not have a drink, but this might be the culture of the place. No more for me, especially if I can go to the best burrito place in town La Taqueria that is not too far from this place.
author: Minerva P.

description:
Pretty much all their food is really good: 

- The dried tomato salsa is fantastic, and they'll refill your chips for free
- Horchata is decent
- Salmon tacos really nice and moist
- Al Pastor highly recommended

Just like Farolito their portions are gigantic. I usually eat 70% of the taco with my fork before rolling the taco.
author: X O.

description: Fried plantain and black bean burrito: You. Complete. Me.
author: Maximillian M.

description: Best Carne Asada. I recommend the Nacho's. Sooo good. And if you call in an order its ready in 5 minutes. The counter people are always super nice. They have a salsa bar.
