This place is a couple more dollars than the other mexican places in town but the quality is well worth it. Check out LIttle Chihahua...!
author: Patricia P.

description: I'll keep this short and simple.  Garlic shrimp burrito and homemade horchata.  Garlic shrimp burrito was loaded full of fresh avocado, sauteed and very tender shrimp, rice, black beans, smoky salsa, pico de gallo.  The tortilla was toasted on the outside.  And it was really good, almost on par with Papalote's Camarones burrito.  Along with Gordo's on Clement, I officially doth proclaim Little Chihuahua to be a third of the Magnificent Three Burrito Clans of San Francisco.
author: Danny K.

description: Wow!!!  So my friends and I called in an order over the phone, 4 of us.  We decided the most effecient was to place the order was to pass the phone and each order what we wanted.  We did so very efficiently.  My friend goes in to the restaurant to pick it up and there is a woman talking sh*t about us and complaining that we passed the phone around to do the ordering.  Worst of all . . . . she thinks it was the manager who was talking the smack!!!  Really?  I mean . . you KNOW we are walking in any minute to pick it up and you are going to talk about us?  How rude; and stupid.  Oh, and they gave us someone else's order to boot!  Maybe you guys should spend less time trash talking and more time getting the order correct.
author: Mariana B.

description: Look, there is nothing wrong with LC.  The place is clean and I appreciate their commitment to local food.  And by SF standards, where Mexi-food can be shockingly disgusting and worlds below anything I have ever seen in Mexico, it is a clear step above.  That said, there is nothing particularly interesting or creative about the dishes, and most of the veggie options are just corn products drowning in cheese.  I would take Baja Fresh over this any day.
author: Sarah S.

description: This place is great, sure it's not 100% authentic Mexican food as other have complained on here, but it is clean, less greasy, and very fresh. The quality is high and the staff is friendly, To go or eat in has always been a great experience for me.
author: R T.

description:
Wow, I read the reviews and came here. Have these people eaten real Mexican food (I guess not).  I was skeptical about them when they first opened so never came. Thought it'd be nice to try them out. Were we wrong. This is not a real Mexican place. It's catered probably to the locals who live in the walking distance, blandness all around.

Got the carnitas burrito...the carnitas were not crispy, they were mushy. There was absolutely no seasoning in this thing...it was blander than baby food.  Actually, it reminded me of it, the texture and the taste. 

Husband ordered some plantain burrito thing and he thought it was gross. We couldn't even finish half of the burrito. 

The salsa had no flavors. Chips were good, but probably because they bought it from an outside source and did not cook it themselves.

Gave 2 stars because the staff was polite and the food came out fast. I would never come back here again. If you want real Mexican food, go a few blocks down towards the mission. We should have done that but thought parking would be easier. If you want semi-bland Mexican food that tastes better than this joint, go to Celia's or Chevy's. I feel totally unsatisfied and ripped off.  They were also playing heavy metal that blasted our ears off, ugh.
author: Elena R.

description: For the price and location, this can't be beat.  Sure, you can go down the hill to the mission but if you are in Noe Valley, sometimes you don't want to go that far. I think the burrito's here are really good and I have always had good service when ordering and the food comes out pretty fast.  The Garlic Shrimp Burrito is my favorite.
author: Adam B.

description: Got the grilled shrimp burrito...loved it...fresh and flavorful.  Friendly and helpful service a plus.  Warm, fresh chips and nice salsa bar.  The guacamole looked great and will have to try next time!  A place to work my way through the menu.....!
author: Susan V.

description:
I was looking forward to this new addition. The music they played was cool and the staff was friendly. The prices wouldn't have bothered me if the food was better. 

For a newcomer to the street and the prices charged I was expecting something better than Casa Mexicana - which is very good, inexpensive, and also on 24th just a couple of blocks away!
author: Addy K.

description:
My first visit, and probably my last.

The al pastor burrito was just awful:  chewy pieces of dried-out meat and other indiscernible ingredients created a burrito of muddled flavors.  All the salsas were, well, muddled too.
author: Shin C.

description: My favorite Mexican food in San Francisco. Baby burritos are plenty big. Vegetable filling really good. Salsa bar and free chips. Not too expensive.
author: Chelsea F.

description:
As the rating implies, "Meh, I've experienced better."  The actual layout, setup, workers, etc. are all really good, but the food is simply mediocre.  I ordered the carnitas super burrito and there was nothing super about it.  If i go "super," I expect a decent amount of guacamole and sour cream; they basically put none.  

To give some context, I love La Corneta's and El Farolito's burritos.  The Little Chihuahua has a much nicer venue, but very mediocre food.
author: Arie J.

description: I expected a lot more of this place after seeing all the yelp reviews. It is a mix of a taco bell and an actual taqueria. The carne asada is plain and boring. The salsa selection was good but nothing to rave about. It is a good place to grab a quick lunch and thats about it.
author: Darius A.

description: I really like this place! When I moved from the Mission up to Noe Valley I really miss Mexican food. Although this place doesn't have that authentico funky feel of a Mission Taqueria, the food is very good and very fresh. They have a have a pozole soup that is really good. Beers on tap, good wine. Definitely a bit more upscale than your typical Taqueria. And I have found the staff to be very friendly!
author: Heidi C.

description: Very happy to have another casual dining spot on 24th st.  Little Chihuahua is not bad Fresh-Mex at all - a nice broad menu featuring simply, relatively healthy options (tacos, burritos, and the like, with sustainably fished and organic offerings).  Very casual and kid-friendly (yes they have high-chairs, and even a kiddy-menu).  Great salsas at the salsa bar, nice brunch offerings (and respectable chilaquiles).  Nothing mind-blowing, but a nice option to have and a very welcome addition to the list of "places to park your stroller" in Noe Valley.
author: Katy M.

description:
I was happy to see this Cali-twist-on-Mex spot in Noe Valley.
We ordered the nachos which were, meh, not great. The plate was packed with chip-crumbs. Not what you would expect from a restaurant....
On the plus side, their fresh salsa was delicious. 
A good place to grab a Pacifico on draft-only $3, but maybe next time I will try ordering something else.
author: Nigel F.

description:
While the food at Little Chihuahua is good, the service is not.  I am not sure if the order takers/cashiers are just dumb or super stoned (maybe both) when they come to work.  For example, tonight I was looking forward to one of LC's delicious super burritos for dinner.  I called to place to a take-out order. The chick who answered the phone put me on hold for 5 minutes. I hung up and called back and again this little chick-a-dee put me on hold for another 5 minutes.  I called back and when the little chick-a-dumb asked to put me hold again, I said, "No, I've been holding for 10 minutes. Would you please take my order?".  She said, "sure I can take your order but I need to put you on hold for a minute." I hung up and went elsewhere. (Thank goodness LC is not only burrito place in town!) There are multiple other ways the service at LC in Noe Valley disappoints, but hey, it's a burrito place so I am willing to put up with less than intelligent cashiers, but tonight really took the cake (sadly, not the burrito).  

As to not be too critical without offering suggestions or support, this is for the young lady who answered the phone tonight: if you were too busy in the restaurant to take a phone order, why not just say, "I am sorry. We are really busy right now and can only help customers in the restaurant. Would you like to try calling back in 30 minutes?"  Because you did not have the common sense or general curtesy or basic hospitality training to do that, you lost a formerly loyal and regular customers (please see my 3/18/2011 review).  

Possibly your manager will read this and provide you and your fellow order takers with some training on basic customer service.
author: Elizabeth M.

description: Delicious Mexican food with consistently high-quality ingredients.  The atmosphere is relaxed, and they dim the lights and light candles in the evening.  The staff is always friendly, and I love all of their different salsas.  Make sure to get a carafe of their wonderful sangria.
author: Ken K.

description:
I would drive to Noe Valley any day of the week to eat at The Little Chihuahua!  

We ventured out during the holidays looking for a delicious, cost efficient lunch and The LC did not disappoint!  We have been to both locations and tried multiple dishes - we LOVE this place.   Salsa Bar w/ homemade salsa options - perfect!  Garlic shrimp burrito - amazing!  Carnitas Nachos - delish!  Fajita burrito - yum!  A great menu for vegetarians as well - Voted Best Vegetarian Burrito in Best of SF for '10.

A definite must try for everyone!
author: Niki T.

description: I love it, I'm sorry!!! The only -1 star, the bathroom is the size of a port-o-pot..not that I need room, but c'mon I'm a girl!!!! The Garlic Shrimp burrito....ahhh-mazing!! Thank you for opening another location in Noe!!!
author: Joanna H.

description: I know its not an authentic Mexican eatery but I like this place. Never had a bad burrito here. I'd recommend the Chorizo and the Chile Verde Chicken. Always prompt with the take out and nice and relaxed to eat in (when there aren't too many screaming kids).
author: Alex B.

description: Just had a phenomenal plantain burrito - after being disappointed in the past, we requested that the plantains be cooked well done and that made all the difference.
author: Dan R.

description: Love this place.  I live right up the street so have eaten there 5 or 6 times now, and every time the food is solid, affordable.  To be fair, it's still taqueria food, but it's a definite step up in flavor, ingredients and ambiance.  The staff is really friendly too.
author: Craig V.

description:
Great grilled shrimp burritos, and the soups are really good as well, especially the tortilla soup. Everything is pretty tasty and there are a wide array of salsas for your food.

What really sets this place apart is the freshness of the ingredients, the tomatoes just taste really, really, REALLY good. Fresh and sweet, oh sooo goood! NOMNOMNOM.

Also the front part of the restaurant has a couple tables right on the huge window and is great for lunch dinning and people-watching.
author: Andre C.

description: Noe finally has some quality Mexican food!   The Casa Mexicana (across from Whole Foods), which has been in the neighborhood for a while, has always made pretty mediocre, bland stuff.  In the past, if I wanted good carnitas, I had to walk down the hill to the Mission.  Now I have excellent burritos (I highly recommend the garlic shrimp burrito), tacos and tortilla soup just 2 blocks from my apartment.  Everything is fresh and full-flavored, augmented by a delicious array of salsas.  Also, the folks behind the counter are super friendly.  And in general, this is pretty nice place -- it's not your run-of-the-mill SF taqueria.  I hope Little Chihuahua makes it (the space has had a huge amount of turnover since Miss Millie's closed 6 years ago) -- it truly fills a need in Noe.
author: Andrew E.

description: I love this place. Order a super veggie burrito + one plantain. Get. Outta. Town.
author: Lindsay A.

description: Little C is one of the yummiest, though perhaps not most authentic taqueria's in SF. By "authentic" i just mean that this is mexican food for gringos. But they also source their ingredients much more carefully than the average taqueria likely does. I feel ok eating their "sustainable" chicken and shrimp in a way it would be tougher for me to justify elsewhere. They also have one of the best salsa bars around, and they are not miserly at all with the free chips, which I appreciate. I most highly recommend the tortilla soup, which is possibly the perfect soup for a cold SF day.
author: Brian C.

description:
wasnt feelin another burger from barneys cross the way so i thought id try the cold-stone-cup-size-3-strips-of-chicken-w/-tons-of-roasted-corn-soup and a side of their oily plaintains that all together cost me $11+.  suck ass, i forever forget my wallet size is never as large as my appetite for new food.

yeah, i was far away from my favorite spicy caldo de pollo from la pinata/la penca azul in alameda.  i give this soup 2 stars coz it wasnt bad, but anything i drench in a decent verde sauce gets at least 2 stars.
author: Lady K.

description: I love the chicken asada burrito, with a selection of salsas. It's our new go to joint.
author: Shannon B.

description: Finally came back here to try the burritos. j and i both had the carnitas super burritos. $8.25 very filling and tasty. You can definitely taste that the ingredients are better quality than most burrito places. I see they won an award for their plantain black bean burrito so ill try that sometime. we also had carne asada nachos which were very good as well. this is probably our new burrito spot, although i still would not come here for the meal type food b/c its still too $$ and small for a counter type restaurant. also, theyve started serving humphry slocombe ice cream (sp) which ive heard is good.
author: Merredith L.

description: As usual, Yelp reviews were spot on. Terrific food, great staff, fun place and all for a low price. My husband had the cheese enchilada plate and I had the pollo asada. Both came with two enchiladas, as well as some of the best black beans we have ever had, an excellent verde sauce and rice.  We each had a pint of Pacifico draft. The bill was an unbelievable $25.50.  I might add that we are both native Northern Californians (SF & Sacto), in our 60s, so we have certainly had our share of Mexican food.
author: Penny C.

description:
Little Chihuahua fits Noe Valley to a tee.  Its all the things I love about the neighborhood.  Much like Noe Valley in general, I wouldn't recommend it for the die hard foodie.  The atmosphere is great, but it's not going to make your night.  Most weekend tourists will never see it.  It's not an authentico experience.  It's a little too pricey and a little too safe.  Much like Noe Valley.  

But if you're in the area, I highly recommend it.  And if you're living in the neighborhood, you will come to appreciate it.  

I don't stray far from the quesadilla's, tacos, and the occasional burrito, but they are all solid.  The veggie burrito with plaintains and beans is a standout, as is the carne asada quesadilla, my go-to.  Good quality meat, just enough cheese and grease to make you forget your troubles but not enough to make more.  

Little Chihuahua really excels at the extras.  Nice atmosphere and a little outdoor seating.  Fully stocked salsa bar, quick service for take-out, good beer selection.  The mexican chocolate cupcakes are a great pick-me-up for the Mrs. or as a dinner party dessert.   

It's not the Mission.  It's not trying to be the Mission.  And it ain't perfect but it keeps me coming back.
author: Paul E.

description: This is a review for the Little Chihuahua's catering services.  The Little Chihuahua catered for our daughter's first bday party at Julius Kahn Park and I can't recommend them enough.  If you are looking for great food and great service for your event, look no further.  We  had a party of 50 and ordered the taco bar and tostada salad for adults and quesadillas for the kids.  Taco bar came with rice, beans, chips, tortillas, cheese and an assortment of excellent salsas and  choice of 3 meats.  We had carne asada, pollo asado and al pastor and all were excellent.  Michael (catering manager) was a pleasure to work with and was able to help me order just the right amount of food for our event.  The delivered the food hot and right on time and even helped to set the taco bar up so I could continue visiting with our family and friends.  Everyeone raved about the food.  So glad I found these guys!
author: JR G.

description: I had them make the black bean and plaintain burrito with grilled chicken and a whole wheat tortita, but no cheese and sour cream.  It was out of this world!  We also had the cheese quesadillas, which were sooo tasty.  The salsas also rock.
author: Gerardo C.

description:
maybe the kids who love this place didn't grow up eating Mexican breakfast at home... with actual Mexicans. that's the only thing that might explain all the excitement. my vieja and i went for brunch today and ordered two dishes to share - chilaquiles and mexican french toast.

The Bad:

* the chilaquiles were doused in so much thick & rich sauce and sour cream that any possible crunch or distinguishable flavors had completely collapsed beneath the weight of it all. i made an attempt to scrape some of the goo away, but found it to be mostly a mushy mess. i ended up using the complimentary chips as scoops to supplement what had been ruined on the plate.

* my old lady has a sweet tooth to rival any four year old and even she was overwhelmed by cloying syrup ladled over the two bacon and plantain stuffed tortillas. it came with a side of syrup. using this would send any healthy adult into diabetic shock.

* plantains, if you aren't aware, are a starchier/heartier/less-flavorful relative of your average monkey banana. they are best when served in smaller pieces that have been prepared more aggressively than a regular banana. in the case of the mexifrench "toast" they were either halved or quartered and strangely giant in proportion to the flour tortilla and piece of bacon it was wrapped with. i suppose the soup of syrup on the plate was meant to balance this out. major failure.

* between the two of us hungry people we did not complete one whole dish. sad.

The Notso-Bad:

* the concepts and most of the flavors were actually pretty good. if they had been executed properly this place would have gotten at least two more stars.

* it's clean. muy importante!

*large portions... which is only a good thing if the food is edible. otherwise you can simply take pride in your contribution to the city composting program. sigh.

The Bottom Line:

i love Mexican breakfast more than any other meal known to man so i really wanted this to be as fantastic as the menu promised. alas, i cannot recommend this place and won't likely return. bummer for me :(
author: Prattle P.

description: Best burrito in SF. Attention paid to flavors missed by kitchen sink burritos. Particularly their tortillas, where you can actually taste the flavor. The only prob I have with it is that I am of the age that I remember the Meat Market Cafe. The interior of this place is pretty lame by comparison.
author: k m.

description: Over a decade in SF. From South Texas. Since I like Ranchero food, the Mexican food in the City sucks--in my humble opinion. Finally found N Mexican rice and beans. Plus the Carnegie asada is high quality beef. Sustainable/ local ingredients to boot.
author: Bryan N.

description:
This is one of those places where they do a couple of things really well, and it would be in your best interest to stick to those things. If you stray, well, you may be disappointed. Oh, and they've screwed up my carry-out order on multiple occasions, so if you call in for take-out, make sure you double check what's in the bag before you leave with your food. This is how I've accidentally/unfortunately ended up eating some of their sub-par dishes, like the vegetarian tostada. Maybe that dish doesn't travel well, but either way... barf.

The garlic shrimp burrito is legit though. Just stick to that and you'll be happy.
author: C C.

description: I live in Noe valley, and am very happy this place opened up!   Very yummy and relatively cheap Mexican food (meal + drink runs ~$12).   Not to mention they have a salsa bar!   Would recommend to anyone, and I plan to go back!
author: Dan P.

description:
I love the black bean and plantain burrito as well as the salsa bar.
nice space, friendly staff.

i do think it's a little more expensive than i'd like especially compared to portion size but i'll still be coming back for more.
author: Sean R.

description: Best burritos in SF.  We get the black bean and plantain burrito probably twice a week.   People that work there are always really nice and most have our order memorized.
author: C S.

description: the super baby buritto was pretty decent. the ingredients tasted great. i enjoyed their chips and different salsas. i do plan to come back to try other items on the menu!
author: Ange G.

description: On my first visit, I had the chicken burrito. It was good, but nothing out of the ordinary. Since it's in the hood,  I conveniently made a second visit, but this time a patron in line told me to try the black bean and plantain burrito. She was right. It was short of amazing. I love black beans in my burrito and the thick cut of plantain, had a nice meat like texture and sweetness. I don't know if it's an acquired taste, but I loved it. I'll be back again for sure. It's a bit on the pricey side for burritos, but that's expected on the Noe side of 24th Street.
author: Fil L.

description:
I gave it 5 stars because I do think this is as good as it gets...in the SF/Bay Area.  I've been living here for almost 11 years and I have yet to find that San Diego/SoCal hole-in-the-wall taco shop flavor that I so crave!  But that doesn't mean that I can't enjoy good Mexican food and there's plenty to be had in the Bay Area.  

Their carne asada is definitely above average.  All of their meals are made to order so when I asked for a sample and got denied, I was intrigued.  I ordered their regular tacos with the rice/beans combo.  The meat was tender, had lots of flavor and was clearly of higher quality than what you normally find in a small taco shop (I think they use Niman Ranch, if I remember correctly).  Their carnitas are also good, but then carnitas are hard to screw up, much like pizza (it has to be a disaster for me to reject pizza/carnitas).  Their chicken was decent but then I don't get excited about chicken...

The black beans were really good; not too soupy but not too thick either.   Although if I had to pick one, I'd go with the thicker-style beans.  Their rice was also surprisingly good.  Not many restaurants place an emphasis on rice and maybe you dont need to, but LC's rice was really flavorful.  They have a great salsa bar too with lots of options.

I've tried their Chicken Tortilla Soup but I didn't think it was all that great.  In fact, I probably wouldn't order it again simply because I can easily get a better soup elsewhere.  Unfortunately, the best tortilla soup previously  available (in my opinion) was at Palapas restaurant in the Financial District, but that closed down in 2008 (rest of their food was degrading quickly so not surprised, plus the whole financial crisis).  If you want a good or decent tortilla soup, go to Whole Foods and get theirs BUT, you have to dress it up!  I add a lot of red chili flakes, black pepper, some lime, chopped red onion, shredded extra-sharp cheddar, avocado, good quality tortilla chips (Primavera chips also available at WF, expensive but well worth it!) and of course cilantro.  Without these ingredients, I cannot stand by the soup at Whole Foods as it will taste completely different; rather bland actually.

Anyway, Little Chihuahau has my support for Mexican food.  Made-to-order yet still quick-serve, good quality and all at a good price!
author: Giggity Giggity G.

description: This place has just what Noe needs, yummy food in a casual environment.  The employees are very nice and really take the time to make sure your order is right (I hate cilantro, so I really appreciate it when my order is correct).  The only problem is that Little Chihuahua is extremely overpriced.
author: Roberta J.

description: My wife and I have eaten here numerous times and really like the food. On 1/21/2014 we had a super pollo burrito and a pollo taco. We also had roasted tomato salsa and chips. Approx. 5 hours later I started to feel extremely nauseous followed by my wife 1 hour later. We both became violently ill and I wouldn't wish that pain on anyone. Undoubtedly, food poisoning due to the simultaneous oncoming of the illness with us both. We also both had flu shots and our two children didn't get sick so it wasn't the flu. I did some digging and found some other yelp reviews about food poisoning at TLC. I sent an email to my companies distro warning them and even had a couple people respond with similar stories about this place. I've eaten food in some shady places all over the world and never once had food poisoning. Whatever these guys are doing they need to clean up their act. If anyone else got sick around this date I encourage you to write SF Dept of public health.
author: matt l.

description: i would give the Noe location of Lil C 10 stars if i could. chris is an awesome manager and we love everyone there. the outside seating option is awesome (heated benches, people!) and the atmosphere is a little more chill than the Divis location - as in - less fighting for a table/being given disdainful looks by hipsters chill. sure, there are often a lot of kids, so what- it's noe valley, what do you expect? we probably eat here too much, but whatever, when you are treated as well as we are and the food is this good, why the heck not?
author: Ellen S.

description:
For being quick, close, extremely clean and delicious I have to give this place 5 stars.  There are tons to choose from on the menu.

If you order pollo asado, you don't get grizzly meat, it is wonderful, white meat grilled perfectly. The salsa have tons of flavor.  The guacamole isn't mixed with any other salsa verde or what not to "water" it down.

The chicken tortilla soup is spicy and great as well.

My boyfriend keeps getting the burritos and won't venture on to anything else because they are too good.

I don't know why this place doesn't have better ratings.  It is a mexican joint, you can't rate taqueria's on par with finer dining.
author: Alexandra F.

description: A fresh new addition to Noe Valley. Nice touch of truly fresh ingredients served either to go or to dine in. Had the guacamole enchiladas, a new concept to me, and fajita steak enchilada. Not fancy, just very clean, pure flavors, not oily, NOT over cheesy. If you want good quality Mexican (Sonoran) cuisine but in a much healthier, less fatty context, this is the place.  PLUS, they have Pacifico and Negro Modelo ON TAP.
author: Nicolas E.

description:
The food, service, and atmosphere at the Little Chihuahua is pleasant. 

But it is overpriced for what it is. Check out Casa Mexicana before you eat here.
author: Catherine L.

description: I am going to give this place some love, because I think the food is good and the service is nice. I ate a chicken burrito this evening and was really impressed by the flavor.  I wanted to eat another. Maybe I was just really hungry, but I usually can't finish an entire burrito. I wish it were a little cheaper too, but I think the price is about right for San Francisco. If you live in the neighborhood, I think you will be quite happy to frequent this place. (yeah, whatever, there's another place, but I don't think it's worth mentioning.)
author: G F.

description: Carnitas tostada and salmon tacos are fabulous.  Service is fast and the staff is terrific.
author: Kurt M.

description: Very tasty! I was a fan of the Divis location for years, but it wasn't always to convenient to get to. Was thrilled when the Noe Lil C opened. The Super Chicken with black beans is a "go to." Always important in Noe is their solid kids menu too!
author: David R.

description: I love this place and lately, with all my late-night and early-morning work commitments, I would probably have starved to death if not for Little Chihuahua (okay, maybe I wouldn't have starved, but I certainly would have had cereal for dinner... again). My favorite menu items of the moment are the wild mushroom burrito (spinach tortilla + non-vegetarian refried beans) -- either with or without cheese (depends how wild I'm feeling) -- or the carne asada burrito, but everything I've tasted here is delicious. I especially appreciate their call-in and take-out service. The counter folks are fast, polite, and friendly and they always make sure you know which location you are contacting (so you and your burrito may be properly united in carnivorous or non-carnivorous bliss). They keep your order nice and hot while you are en route and they have NEVER messed up an order for me yet! Love them, love them, love them.
author: Fromage S.

description:
Tonight was my third visit since it opened a few weeks ago.

LIKES:
Really Nice Staff
Super High Quality Ingredients
Great Salsa Bar
The Best Chips
Homemade Horchata
Interesting Space & Art

BESTEST LIKE:
Hands Down, the Pork Pozole Rojo

DISLIKE: 
The Burrito Tortillas
(Warmed = warm, soft and slightly chewy. Good things. Toasted = charred, hard and dry, they fall apart and make for a messy eating experience. Not so good things. Will skip the burritos there unless this changes.)

OVERALL:
Four Stars. Welcome. What a really great addition to the neighborhood, except for the unfortunate toasted thing going on.
author: Richard F.

description:
A very good addition to 24th St!!  My burrito was top notch and my wife's plantain burrito was divine. The salsa bar was also great, especially the fruity (but not too hot) habanero salsa. 

The service was good, and the inside seating small but well done. And of course it's kid friendly. 

I will definitely be going back.
author: Paul G.

description: what a great addition to the neighborhood!  it's nice to have something in the old miss millie's space that doesn't suck.  their food definitely feels like california-style mexican food, but it's good.  i especially like their nachos, their shrimp tacos, and their veggie buritto with plaintains and black beans.  their salsa bar is pretty good, too, and they make some tasty sangria!  i'm a fan for sure.
author: Erin C.

description:
i like the food, but the sangria and margaritas didn't really do it for me.  it's a much better alternative to casa mexicana II. 

i really appreciated how the to-go orders are packaged here.
author: B N.

description: black bean and fried plantain burrito, we should talk. things between us are moving waaay too fast, but I love the wind in my hair. you've got me wrapped around your little chipotle finger--and you know it.
author: Ryan H.

description: Yum! My two simple suggestions ... 1. Carnitas tacos with chilpolte salsa from salsa bar.  The carnitas is great and the meat on one taco is enough for two normal sized tacos.  Squeeze on the lime and spoon on the smokey salsa and it's delicious.  2. Nachos - Even if you're not stoned you will feel that vague sense of munchie relief eating these nachos.  How can you not be transported back to that stinky college room with a plate of crisp tortilla chips, melted cheese, sour cream, guacamole, salsa, and black beans in front of you?
author: Mary H.

description: Great service at this casual Mexican joint. Wonderful bunch of vegetarian burritos on the menu. I hear the chicken tortilla soup is great from my friends who are omnivores. Love that there's good beer on tap, and from well kept kegs. They even serve some decent wines! (Though malbec and a burrito seems like a weird pairing to me.) There's a back patio space that's nice enough. Lots of tables. Good for groups. Affordable! Enjoy.
author: Lorae K.

description: Good burritos. I am from New Mexico so took me a little getting used to the California style of burrito. All fresh ingredients and good salsa. Love it. Also serve beer and sangria. Love the super baby chile verde chicken burrito.
author: julie q.
